This is a group-level whole-brain contrast (Cooperation > Competition) from a hyperscanning social interaction task in healthy adult pairs, indexing interpersonal brain–behavior dependencies related to goal (cooperation vs competition). It is task-evoked, voxelwise, and directly measures social processing; it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison.

This is a group-level, whole-brain contrast comparing cooperation > competition from a task that explicitly manipulates affiliation/goal structure (cooperation vs competition). The sample appears to be healthy adult interactants, the contrast maps a task-evoked effect (main effect of goal), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison — therefore it meets the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (Cooperation > Competition) from a healthy adult hyperscanning sample examining goal structure (cooperation vs competition). Cooperation/competition is listed as an example task measuring Perception and Understanding of Self, and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain group-level contrast (Cooperation > Competition) from a hyperscanning study of healthy adult pairs probing goal structure in social exchange. The task (cooperation vs competition) is an exemplar social-communication measure, and the reported result is a univariate main-effect map (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain contrast (Cooperation > Competition) from a task that directly probes social exchange (cooperation vs competition), fitting the Perception/Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical comparison, and the sample appears to be healthy adult interactants, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (Competition > Cooperation) derived from a hyperscanning social interaction task in healthy adult pairs, indexing interpersonal brain–behavior dependencies tied to a social goal manipulation. It is task-evoked, not an ROI or seed/connectivity analysis, and directly measures social processing (cooperation vs competition).

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast probing goal structure (competition vs cooperation) in healthy interacting adults. Cooperation vs competition is an example task probing affiliation/attachment, so the Competition > Cooperation contrast qualifies as measuring the affiliation dimension.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, voxelwise group-level contrast (Competition > Cooperation) indexing a social-exchange dimension (cooperation vs competition) in presumably healthy adult dyads. It is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical contrast, and directly assesses a Social Communication task dimension, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain contrast (Competition > Cooperation) from a healthy adult hyperscanning study examining cooperation vs. competition (a task class listed under Perception and Understanding of Self). The reported clusters reflect a main effect of goal (not an ROI, seed-based, or between-group contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level task contrast comparing competition vs cooperation (goal structure) during a social interaction task in healthy adults. It reflects whole-brain, voxelwise univariate effects of a social exchange manipulation (cooperation/competition), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group clinical contrast.

This is a whole-brain, group-level contrast from a hyperscanning social interaction task (cooperation vs competition, role interaction). The sample is healthy adults, the contrast indexes social processing (goal-by-role effects during interpersonal exchange), and it is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or a clinical between-group comparison. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast concerns cooperation versus competition (goal structure) — a task directly relevant to affiliation/attachment (cooperation vs competition). The reported result is a group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrast (clusters expressing a goal-by-role interaction) from a healthy sample in a within-group task analysis, not an ROI or seed/connectivity or patient-vs-control between-group contrast. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes cooperation vs competition (COO > COM), which is a Social Communication task (cooperation/competition). The reported results are group-level whole-brain voxelwise clusters of interpersonal brain–behavior dependencies (iBBDs), not ROI/seed/connectivity or a patient-vs-control between-group comparison. Although the table describes a goal-by-role interaction, this is a within-study task interaction (not a patient-group contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise task contrast derived from a healthy adult sample that tests cooperation vs. competition (a task type listed under Perception and Understanding of Self). The reported clusters reflect whole-brain iBBD effects (brain–behavior dependencies) for a goal (COO>COM) by role interaction within the task, not an ROI/seed-based connectivity or clinical between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise group contrast derived from healthy adult hyperscanning participants comparing goal conditions (cooperation vs competition) and roles (builder vs other). The task probes social exchange (cooperation/competition), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others, and the reported clusters reflect voxelwise effects (not ROI, seed-based connectivity, or a clinical between-group contrast). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise cluster results (iBBDs) from a dual‑fMRI task that manipulates goal structure (cooperation vs competition) during social exchange. Participants are healthy adults and the contrast indexes social cognition / interpersonal processing (responses to a co-player), so it meets the sample, whole-brain, and social-processing inclusion criteria and does not fall under the exclusion rules.

The reported analysis reflects a goal-by-role interaction (contrast: Other (COO>COM) > Builder (COO>COM)), i.e. a between-role interaction/subgroup comparison rather than a simple within-group main effect. The inclusion rules exclude between-group contrasts or interactions, so this analysis should not be included despite the task (cooperation vs competition) and likely healthy sample.

Although the task (cooperation vs competition) and sample/contrast are consistent with social_communication and the results appear to be whole-brain group maps, this specific analysis is a goal-by-role interaction (Other (COO>COM) > Builder (COO>COM)). The exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts or interactions, so this interaction contrast should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast related to cooperation versus competition (goal dimension), which falls squarely within the Perception and Understanding of Self domain (cooperation/competition). The reported maps reflect interpersonal brain–behavior dependencies derived from task-evoked effects (not ROI, seed/connectivity, or a patient vs control comparison). Although the table text references a goal-by-role interaction, this is a within-task factorial effect (not a between-group clinical contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a task-evoked, group-level whole-brain voxelwise analysis of interpersonal brain-behavior dependencies during a social interaction task (cooperation vs. competition) collected in pairs of participants (hyperscanning). It targets social processing (responses to a partner's actions) in a healthy adult sample and is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrast from a hyperscanning task that manipulates social goal structure (cooperation vs competition), which directly maps onto Perception/Understanding of Others. The contrast (COO>COM) and its goal-by-role interaction are within-task condition comparisons in healthy adult pairs (not patient vs control), and the reported results are cluster maps (not ROI or seed/connectivity analyses). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis is the "main effect of Interaction," i.e. interaction structure (concurrent vs turn‑based), not the goal dimension (cooperation vs competition) that probes affiliation/attachment. Although the study includes cooperation/competition, this specific contrast does not index affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the criterion that the analysis/contrast measure Affiliation and Attachment.

This is a group-level whole-brain voxelwise analysis from a hyperscanning study of healthy adult pairs examining social exchange dimensions (cooperation vs competition / interaction structure). The table reports clusters for a main effect of goal/interaction in an interpersonal brain–behavior dependency (iBBD) contrast tied to cooperation/competition, which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (e.g., cooperation vs competition). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain contrast from a healthy adult hyperscanning task that manipulates social goal (cooperation vs. competition), i.e., a social-communication dimension (cooperation/competition). The result reports clusters (voxelwise/cluster inference) for a main effect (not an ROI, seed/connectivity, resting-state, or a between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast from a healthy-adult hyperscanning study of cooperation/competition (which meets some task criteria), the specific contrast is the main effect of Interaction (interpersonal/interaction structure and iBBDs to a partner's actions). That contrast indexes interpersonal/interaction dynamics and responses to the co-player (social cognition about others) rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. The analysis therefore does not specifically measure Perception and Understanding of Self and should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast from a hyperscanning study of social exchange (goal structure × interaction structure), in healthy adult pairs, indexing interpersonal brain responses to partner behavior. It assays social processing (social interaction/understanding) and is not an ROI, seed/connectivity, or between-group clinical contrast.

The analysis concerns a within-subject task manipulation of goal (cooperation vs competition) — a prototypical affiliation/attachment task — in a healthy adult hyperscanned sample. The reported results are voxelwise whole-brain clusters (iBBDs), not ROI/seed or between-group contrasts, so it meets the inclusion criteria for affiliation_attachment.

The analysis tests task factors (goal: cooperation vs competition; interaction structure) from a dual‑fMRI task that directly probes social exchange (cooperation/competition), and reports group‑level voxelwise clusters of interpersonal brain‑behavior dependencies (iBBDs). The sample is healthy adult dyads (not a clinical comparison), and the reported maps are whole‑brain task‑evoked effects rather than ROI, seed‑connectivity, or between‑group clinical contrasts. Therefore it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise task fMRI analysis contrasting goal structure (cooperation vs competition) during an interpersonal interaction task (hyperscanning). It directly probes Perception/Understanding of Others (cooperation vs competition) and is reported as whole-brain clusters of iBBDs rather than an ROI, seed/connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis of interpersonal brain–behavior dependencies (iBBDs) for goal structure (cooperation vs. competition) in a healthy adult hyperscanned sample. The task (cooperation/competition) maps onto the Perception and Understanding of Self construct, and the reported clusters reflect within-group task effects (not ROI, seed/connectivity, or patient vs. control contrasts). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast probes regret (a cognitively-generated negative emotion) in a gambling/observation task, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, cooperation). It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast index affiliation/attachment.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast from a healthy adult sample testing observed (other) regret and its overlap with first-person regret (conjunction of IP and OP). The task probes understanding of others' regret (a social perception/understanding process), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a within-group, task-evoked, parametric conjunction contrast from a healthy adult sample probing observation/understanding of another's regret/disappointment (social cognition). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate parametric contrast from a healthy adult sample probing regret experienced and observed in others (conjunction of self (IP) and other (OP) conditions). The task explicitly examines understanding/observation of another's regret (Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, univariate parametric analysis in healthy adults (Study 1) that contrasts first‑person and other‑person regret (conjunction IP and OP). The task involves perceiving/understanding another person's regretful outcome (social perception/interaction — akin to reception of non‑facial social communication/social comparison), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between‑group analysis. Therefore it meets the "social_communication" inclusion criteria.

This analysis probes regret/disappointment in a gambling task (first‑person and observed regret) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although likely a whole‑brain, healthy adult within‑group contrast, it does not assess affiliation/attachment processes, so it fails the task/contrast inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, task-evoked parametric conjunction (IP-IF and OP-OF) from a study explicitly about observing others' regret/disappointment, i.e., understanding others' emotional states. It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast and aligns with the Perception/Understanding of Others construct. (Table caption/description mismatch noted but does not change inclusion.)

This analysis is a conjunction of first‑person (IP) and other‑person (OP) regret conditions (overlap between experiencing and observing regret). The contrast targets shared self/other processing (understanding others) rather than a map that specifically measures perception/understanding of the self alone. Because the reported map is a conjunction emphasizing overlap with observing another's regret (not a self‑focused contrast), it does not meet the requirement that the analysis specifically measures Perception and Understanding of Self.

This is a group-level, within-subject parametric conjunction contrast examining observation of another person's regret/disappointment (a receptive judgment of another's emotional state). It was performed in a healthy adult sample and is reported as a whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria (fits receptive/affect-recognition / reception of non-facial communication).

This contrast tests parametric regret/disappointment responses in both first‑person and observed/other conditions (a conjunction of IP and OP) and was designed to probe shared neural responses to experiencing and observing regret. It targets emotion processing and vicarious/empathic understanding of others rather than explicit Perception/Understanding of the self (self‑knowledge or self‑monitoring) as defined by the 'perception_self' construct, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes regret (a counterfactual, decision-related emotion) in a gambling/observer paradigm, not affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Although it appears to be a healthy, whole-brain group task contrast, it does not measure affiliation/attachment and thus fails the task-domain inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (parametric analysis/conjunction of IP and OP regret conditions) that probes understanding/observation of others' regret — a social-cognitive process (Perception/Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis. The study and contrast target social processing in healthy adults, so it meets the inclusion criteria.
This analysis is a between-group contrast (Females > Males). The inclusion criteria exclude subgroup vs subgroup or between-group contrasts, so it should not be included despite being a social task.

This is a group-level, voxelwise parametric conjunction contrast that includes the OP (observing another's regret) condition (conjoined with IP), from a healthy adult sample. It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis and directly probes perception/understanding of others' emotional states (observed regret), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast probes observers' understanding of another person's regret (observing regretful outcomes), which constitutes reception of socially relevant, non-facial communication about another's emotional state. The study reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activations in a healthy adult sample (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria for the social_communication annotation.

This is a between-group contrast (Females > Males), which is excluded by the criteria. In addition, the task/contrast probes regret (observation/experience of others' regret), which does not target affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole‑brain group analysis on healthy adults, the contrast is a conjunction of self- and other-regret conditions (IP and OP) targeting shared/‘mirror’ responses to others' regret. It does not specifically probe perception/understanding of the self (self-knowledge or agency) required for the "perception_self" label, so it should be excluded.

This is a between-group (Females > Males) contrast, which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. In addition, the contrast appears to index observation of others' regret (other-focused) rather than Perception/Understanding of the self, so it does not match the 'perception_self' construct.

The contrast is a between-group (Females > Males) comparison of OP minus OF (a sex difference interaction), which falls under the exclusion criterion for between-group contrasts/subgroup comparisons. Although the task involves observing others' regret (relevant to perception/understanding of others), the analysis is not a within-group, whole-brain effect generalizable to the healthy adult population and thus should be excluded.

This contrast is a between-group comparison (Males > Females) of OP minus OF, i.e. a sex difference interaction, which falls under the exclusion criteria for between-group contrasts. Although the task probes social processing (observing others' regret) and likely uses whole-brain univariate analysis on healthy adults, the between-group nature disqualifies it.

Excluded. The contrast is a between-group comparison (Males > Females), which falls under the exclusion criterion for subgroup/between-group contrasts. In addition, the task probes regret (a cognitive emotion) rather than an affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group (sex) contrast (Males > Females). The exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts/subgroup comparisons. Even though the task involves observing others' regret (social cognition), the specific analysis is a group comparison and thus not eligible.

The reported contrast is a between-group sex comparison (Females > Males). Between-group contrasts/interactions are excluded by the criteria. Additionally, although the task probes observation of others' regret (social/empathic processing), the contrast is not a within-group whole-brain task effect measuring Social Communication for the healthy adult sample.

This is a between-group contrast (Males > Females), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. In addition, the contrast pertains to observing others' regret (understanding others) rather than Perception/Understanding of the self, so it does not match the target construct.

This analysis is a between-group contrast (Males > Females) rather than a within-group, whole‑brain univariate map of healthy adults. The exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts/interactions, so it should not be included despite the task targeting understanding others' regret.

The contrast is a between-group comparison (Females > Males). Even though the task probes social processing (observing others' regret) and likely uses whole-brain fMRI, subgroup vs subgroup contrasts are excluded per the criteria.

This contrast probes sex differences (Females > Males), i.e. a between-group comparison which is excluded. In addition, the task probes regret (a cognitively-generated emotion) rather than affiliation/attachment processes, so it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a between-group comparison (Females > Males). Even though the task concerns understanding others' regret (a social process) and likely used whole-brain univariate maps, the inclusion criteria exclude subgroup/between-group contrasts or interactions, so this analysis should not be included.

This contrast indexes regret processing (observing others' regret), not affiliation/attachment, and it is a between-group sex comparison (Males > Females). It therefore does not meet the task/content requirement and also violates the exclusion of between-group contrasts.

The contrast is a between-group (Females > Males) comparison. Even though the task targets perception/understanding of others (observing regret), the inclusion rules exclude subgroup/between-group contrasts, so this analysis should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (Females > Males), which is explicitly excluded. In addition, the contrast (OP minus OF) appears to concern observation of others' regret (other-person conditions) rather than a task measuring Perception/Understanding of the self, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Males > Females) of OP−OF. The inclusion criteria exclude between-group/subgroup contrasts; although the task is social (observing others' regret), this analysis is a sex comparison and therefore should be excluded.

This is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (toss vs button press) from a healthy adult sample performing a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss). It measures social processing (response to increased social interaction/social reward), and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.
This is a between-group contrast (Males > Females). The inclusion criteria exclude between-group contrasts/interactions (subgroup vs subgroup), so this analysis should not be included.

The reported contrast is a between-group comparison (Males > Females). The exclusion criteria disallow subgroup/ between-group contrasts (e.g., subgroup vs subgroup), so this analysis should not be included despite involving observation of others' regret.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (toss – button press) from a healthy adult sample (N=38) probing social interaction frequency in a ball-toss task. The task measures social interaction/cooperation/inclusion, which falls under Social Communication, and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (toss – button press) from healthy adult participants in a social ball-toss paradigm that manipulates frequency of positive social interaction. The task probes social/affiliative interaction and reward from social contact (fits affiliation/attachment), and the reported result is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast ((toss – button press) high-frequency) in a healthy adult sample (N=38). The task manipulates social interaction frequency and the reported activation (precuneus) is interpreted as reflecting positive self‑image/self‑related processing, fitting the Perception and Understanding of Self construct. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between‑group contrast.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (high-frequency toss vs button press) from a healthy adult sample playing a social ball-toss game. It indexes social interaction/social reward (affiliation), is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group comparison, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a between-group (Males > Females) contrast, which meets the exclusion criterion prohibiting between-group contrasts/interactions. This analysis does not meet the inclusion criteria. Exclude. Although the study used healthy adults and probed person-related processing, the reported analysis focuses on anterior temporal lobe activations (and the paper used conjunction and ROI and resting-state connectivity approaches). It is not clearly a whole‑brain, group-level univariate task map measuring a Social Communication contrast (the task involved encoding facts about people vs buildings vs hammers — a person-selectivity / social-cognition manipulation rather than an explicit social-communication task), and ROI/resting-state analyses are flagged as exclusions. This contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexes observation of others' goal-directed hand actions (action perception), not processes of self‑awareness, agency, or self‑knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct. (Additionally, the study includes a patient group, so it may not be a pure healthy‑only group contrast.)

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexing perception of others' actions — a social processing task (perception/understanding of others). Although the study also included patients, the reported contrast reflects within-group activation to action observation (healthy participants), not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexing observation of others' hand actions (Action Perception subconstruct) reported at PFWE<0.05. It reflects healthy participants' data (the study reports healthy controls and the contrast is not a between-group comparison), and is not an ROI/ connectivity analysis—therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This contrast reflects action observation (perception of others' hand movements), not a task probing affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group contrast, its cognitive domain does not match the affiliation_attachment criteria.

This contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexes perception of goal-directed hand actions / kinematics (action observation), not an exchange of socially relevant communicative signals. Although likely a healthy group whole-brain contrast, the task does not measure Social Communication (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communicative behaviours) as defined by the annotation criteria.

Healthy adult participants; group-level, task-evoked whole-brain voxelwise analysis correlating brain activation with self-reported urge to imitate; the task involves observation/imitation (a social behavior relevant to perception/understanding of others and social interaction), and the analysis is not ROI-, seed-, resting-state-, or between-group. Therefore it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexes observation of other people's hand actions (perception of others' actions), not processes of perceiving or evaluating the self. Although it appears to be a within-subject whole-brain contrast (and likely from healthy participants), it does not meet the construct requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

Although the study used healthy adults and reports a whole-brain voxelwise correlation with self-reported 'urge to imitate', the task and contrast probe an imitation drive for meaningless actions rather than affiliation or attachment (no measures of close relationships, attachment style, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation, etc.). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexing action perception (Perception of Others: Action Perception). It appears to be a voxelwise whole-brain group contrast from the healthy participants (study reports healthy subjects, n=31) rather than an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level, whole-brain analysis in healthy adults (correlation of activation with urge to imitate), the task measures an internal imitation drive to meaningless bimanual actions rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or an explicit social communication process. It therefore does not meet the requirement that the contrast/task measure Social Communication.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activity with participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate'—an internal self-evaluative state. That matches the Perception and Understanding of Self construct (self-awareness/internal states) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

Healthy adult participants; a group-level whole-brain univariate analysis reporting voxels whose activation correlated with participants' urge to imitate observed bimanual actions. The task probes action perception / spontaneous imitation (fits the Action Perception subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analysis in healthy adults (brain activations correlated with self-reported 'urge to imitate'). The task probes spontaneous imitation, a social/communicative process relevant to social processing, and the analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group contrast.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level correlation in healthy adults, the task measures an "urge to imitate" for meaningless actions (spontaneous imitation/motor drive), not affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation, bonding). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assess Affiliation and Attachment.

Although the analysis is a whole‑brain, within‑group correlation in healthy adults, the task probes urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (motor imitation drive) rather than exchange or processing of socially relevant communicative signals. This does not meet the social_communication construct (production/reception of facial or non‑facial communicative behaviors), so it should be excluded.

The analysis correlates whole-brain, group-level activation with participants' subjective "urge to imitate," which is an introspective judgment about a current internal state (self-monitoring/self-knowledge). The sample is healthy adults and the analysis is a univariate voxelwise task-evoked map (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the perception_self inclusion criteria.

This is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) / seed-based connectivity analysis (functional connectivity), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. In addition, the task measures 'urge to imitate' rather than an affiliation/attachment contrast. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise task-evoked analysis in healthy adults reporting whole-brain activations that correlate with subjects' urge to imitate observed actions. The task probes perception/processing of others' actions (Action Perception subconstruct) rather than an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) / seed-based functional connectivity analysis (per the table title). The annotation requires group-level univariate, task-evoked whole-brain contrasts; connectivity/seed-based (PPI) analyses are explicitly excluded.

This is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analysis, which falls under seed-based/effective connectivity and is explicitly excluded. The inclusion criteria require a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) activation map, which this is not.

This is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analysis (seed-based effective connectivity), which the criteria explicitly exclude. It is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation contrast required for the 'perception_others' annotation.

Although the sample is healthy adults and the reported analysis appears to be a within-group, voxelwise correlation, the task measures spontaneous imitation/urge to imitate meaningless actions rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the content criterion for an affiliation_attachment annotation.

This analysis is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) seed-based connectivity/effective connectivity analysis. The annotation excludes seed-based/effective connectivity (e.g., PPI, DCM); it is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast, so it should be excluded.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adults, it probes the urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (spontaneous imitation/motor mirroring) rather than exchange or processing of socially communicative signals. It does not measure reception/production of facial or non-facial communication in a communicative/social-information context, so it does not meet the "social_communication" construct.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise correlation in healthy adults (not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast). The task probes observation/imitation of others' actions and the "urge to imitate," which indexes a social/perceptual-motivational aspect of imitation (a social processing construct), so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

The analysis reports a voxelwise, whole-brain group-level correlation between BOLD and participants' 'urge to imitate' during observation of others' actions in healthy adult subjects. This probes Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult participants; group-level, task-evoked whole-brain voxelwise correlation (Urge) during an imitation task; imitation is a social-processing construct (perception/understanding and social behavior). Not an ROI, between-group, or connectivity analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults (correlation of BOLD with subjective 'urge to imitate'), which is an introspective judgment about a current internal state. It is task-evoked, not an ROI/seed/connectivity or between-group contrast, and therefore fits the Perception and Understanding of Self (self-monitoring/internal state) inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a group-level, whole-brain univariate correlation in healthy adults, the task measures the urge to imitate meaningless actions (spontaneous imitation) rather than affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the domain requirement for Affiliation/Attachment.

The analysis measures neural correlates of an urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (motor imitation drive) rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behavior. Although imitation can relate to social learning, this task does not assess reception/production of communicative signals (facial or non‑facial) as defined by the social_communication construct, so it does not meet the task-based inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample; the reported analysis is a group-level voxelwise correlation between brain activation and participants' self-rated 'urge to imitate' — an introspective evaluation of an internal state (self-monitoring/urge), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Self construct. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise task analysis in healthy adult participants linking brain activation to 'urge to imitate' during an imitation/observation task. The task is social (spontaneous imitation/perception of others' actions) and the contrast measures a social-processing-related variable. It is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise regression in healthy adult participants linking brain activation to the subjective 'urge to imitate' during observation/imitation of others' actions. The task assesses action perception (perception of others' movements), not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast, so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Others (action perception) inclusion criteria.

The analysis probes the neural correlates of an 'urge to imitate' meaningless actions (imitation drive), not measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain group task analysis in healthy adults, the task and contrast do not assess affiliation or attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

Although the analysis is a group-level, whole-brain univariate correlation in healthy adults, the task probes an 'urge to imitate' for meaningless bimanual actions rather than exchange or processing of socially communicative signals. The stimuli and contrast do not measure social communication (facial/non‑facial communicative reception or production) as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

This analysis examines neural correlates of the urge to imitate (imitation drive), not measures of affiliation or attachment. Although the study used healthy adults and reported whole-brain correlations, the task/contrast does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The analysis reports a group-level, voxelwise correlation between brain activation and subjects' 'urge to imitate' during an imitation task in healthy adult participants, i.e. a whole-brain univariate task-evoked map (not an ROI or seed-based connectivity). The task (spontaneous imitation) assesses a social behavior relevant to social processing (social learning/interaction), so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole‑brain task activation/correlation from healthy adults collected during observation of others' actions (action perception). Although the analysis label is "Difficulty: Observation," it was derived from the task in which participants watched others' bimanual actions, so it indexes Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between‑group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The listed analysis is labeled 'Difficulty: Observation', which indexes perceived difficulty of observed actions rather than a measure of self-perception/self-knowledge (e.g., agency, internal states about the self). Although the table caption mentions correlations with 'Urge', the specific analysis name/description focuses on difficulty during observation and thus does not clearly assess Perception and Understanding of Self. Therefore it does not meet the construct inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level correlation in healthy adults, the task probes spontaneous imitation of meaningless bimanual actions (urge to imitate) rather than exchange or processing of socially communicative signals. It does not measure social communication per the annotation definition, so it should be excluded.

Healthy adult sample; group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analysis correlating task-evoked activation with participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' (an internal cognitive/emotional state relating to the self). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the perception_self inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adults relating brain activation during observation/imitation of others' actions to subjective 'urge' to imitate. The task probes action perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample; the reported analysis is a group-level, voxelwise search for brain activations correlated with participants' 'urge to imitate' (a task-evoked, whole-brain univariate map). The task (observation/imitation of actions and urge to imitate) taps social processing (spontaneous imitation/social learning), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

The analysis probes an urge to imitate meaningless hand actions (spontaneous imitation), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a whole‑brain, within‑group correlation in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment, so it should be excluded.

Although the study used healthy adults and reported whole-brain task-evoked correlations, the task measured urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (imitation drive) rather than an exchange of socially relevant communicative signals. It does not target reception/production of facial or non‑facial social communication per the annotation definition, so it should be excluded.

Healthy adult participants viewing others' (meaningless bimanual) actions with voxelwise group-level task-evoked activations correlated with subjective 'urge to imitate' — this probes Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others). The analysis is a within-group whole-brain univariate correlation (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adult participants correlating brain activation with subjects' urge to imitate during an imitation task. Imitation/urge to imitate is a social-related process (relevant to social communication and social learning), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults relating brain activation to participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' — an introspective/internal state about the self (self-monitoring/self-knowledge). It is not an ROI, between-group, or connectivity (PPI) analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_self.

The analysis probes the neural correlates of an 'urge to imitate' meaningless actions (spontaneous imitation), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, bonding, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task and contrast do not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) reported with peak coordinates and FDR correction from healthy adult participants (trained dancers). The contrast indexes social interaction/joint action (partnered vs alone), which fits the Social Processing domain. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Healthy adult participants; a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analysis relating task-evoked activation to participants' "urge to imitate" during observation/imitation of others' actions. The task probes Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others). This is not an ROI, between-group, or resting/seed-based connectivity analysis.

Although the analysis is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adults, the task involves observing/imitating meaningless bimanual actions and ratings of an "urge to imitate." This does not constitute exchange of socially relevant information or a social-communication task (e.g., receptive/expressive facial or non‑facial communicative stimuli or interpersonal scenarios). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the contrast measure Social Communication.

Healthy adult sample and a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analysis correlating BOLD with participants' subjective 'urge to imitate' (an explicit evaluation of an internal state). This maps onto the Self-knowledge subconstruct of Perception/Understanding of Self. The reported result is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group contrast (the PPI reported elsewhere in the paper is separate and not the analysis in the table).

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult dancers that isolates social interaction involving physical coupling and coordinated non‑verbal exchange. The task indexes non‑facial social communication (production/reception of interpersonal cues during joint action), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) on healthy adult participants, not an ROI or connectivity analysis. The contrast isolates joint/partnered social interaction (leading/following/mutual) versus solo/alone, which probes perception and understanding of others (action perception/social interaction), so it meets the construct and inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (partnered > non-partnered = Leading+Following+Mutual > Solo+Alone) indexes social/joint-action processing rather than explicit perception or evaluation of the self (agency or self-knowledge). The contrast pools roles (including externally-oriented following and mutual interaction) and does not specifically probe self-awareness, self-monitoring, or judgments about the self, so it does not meet the ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants performing a joint-action (paired/partnered) task. The contrast (Leading relative to other conditions/conjunction) probes role-related processing during a social interaction (joint action), which fits the Social Processing domain. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult participants examining joint/paired action (physical coupling vs solo), which maps onto social cooperation/positive interaction processes relevant to affiliation/attachment. The analysis is not an ROI or connectivity analysis and therefore meets the annotation inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adult participants probing the leader role in joint action. The Leading condition indexes self-oriented/agentic processes (motor planning, action monitoring, agency) relevant to Perception and Understanding of Self, and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants (within-subject roles: leading vs others) and not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis. The task is interpersonal joint action (cooperative physical contact/role signaling), which constitutes non-facial social communication (production/reception via touch/coordination), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses healthy adults and reports whole-brain task contrasts of partnered vs non‑partnered movement, the specific analysis (Leading > Conjunction) reflects role-based motor planning in joint action (leading vs following) rather than an explicit measure of affiliation/attachment (e.g., attachment, close-relationship or cooperation/affiliation contrasts such as loved one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the criterion that the contrast measure Affiliation and Attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult participants performing a social joint-action task. The contrast directly indexes social interaction/processing (partnered vs solo/alone) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast targets the Leading role (self-oriented motor planning/sequencing) rather than perception or understanding of another person. Although the task involves a partner, the analysis (Leading > conjunction) does not directly measure perception/mentalizing or action perception of others (e.g., partnered vs non‑partnered or explicit social/mental state contrasts). Therefore it does not meet the construct requirement for Perception and Understanding of Others.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast on healthy adults, the contrast (partnered > non-partnered) indexes joint action/social coupling and sensorimotor/social cognition rather than processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. It does not operationalize perception/understanding of the self (e.g., self-judgments, agency judgments, social comparison), so it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adult participants engaging in cooperative joint action (leader/follower/mutual roles). The following/partnered vs non-partnered contrasts index interpersonal coordination and exchange of socially relevant non-facial cues (cooperation/role communication), fitting the Social Communication (production/reception of non‑facial communication) construct. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Partnered > Non-partnered) in healthy adult participants (trained dancers) measuring joint action/interaction. The task probes perception/action understanding of another person (action perception/social cognition), and the analysis is not ROI- or connectivity-based nor a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, whole-brain contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adults capturing cooperative/interactive (partnering) behavior. The task probes social interaction/cooperation (an example affiliation task), and the analysis is not ROI- or connectivity-based nor a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast in healthy adult participants probing interactive joint action (partnered/mutual vs solo/alone), which indexes social/cooperative non-verbal communication. It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants comparing a partnered (Mutual) social interaction condition to others. The Mutual condition specifically taps social processing (mentalizing and social reward) during joint action. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the Mutual condition indexes symmetric joint action and (per the abstract) increased mentalizing and social-reward processing rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. The contrast reflects social interaction (partnered vs non‑partnered / mutual) and mentalizing, not perception/understanding of the self as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adult participants involving a social joint-action condition (Mutual) that the authors interpret as engaging mentalizing/social-reward processes. The contrast indexes perception/understanding of another (social interaction/mentalizing) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants comparing partnered (Mutual/Leading/Following) versus non‑partnered (Solo/Alone) conditions of joint action. The task probes cooperative, physically coupled social interaction (mutual/shared movement) and elicits mentalizing and social‑reward activity, which maps onto affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/positive social bonding). Noted caveat: the partner appears to be an experimenter rather than e.g. a long-term attachment figure, but the contrast nonetheless measures affiliative/cooperative interaction and meets the inclusion criteria (whole‑brain, healthy sample, task taps affiliation).

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (improvised vs non-improvised; and self-initiated vs externally-triggered) reported with peak coordinates from healthy adult participants performing a dyadic joint-action task. The task is social (leader/follower, mutual interaction, partnering), so the contrast indexes social processing rather than an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults (partnered > non-partnered) indexing social interaction/cooperation (joint action with physical contact) and engages social-cognitive/ reward processes. It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis and fits the cooperation-type tasks listed in the inclusion examples for affiliation/attachment.

The reported contrast includes a "self-initiated versus externally-triggered" comparison (Leading + Solo + Mutual + Alone > Following), which directly probes agency/self-initiation — a core subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Self. The data are from healthy adult participants and are reported as whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts (Talairach coordinates, FDR-corrected), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the study involves interpersonal joint action, the specific contrast described (improvised vs non‑improvised and self‑initiated vs externally‑triggered) targets improvisation and agency/motor planning rather than the exchange of socially relevant communicative signals (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communication, cooperation/competition contrasts). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the analysis measures Social Communication. (Note: a partnered vs non‑partnered contrast would be more relevant, but that is not the analysis provided.)

The reported contrasts (improvised vs non‑improvised; self‑initiated vs externally‑triggered) probe motor planning, improvisation and agency rather than perception or understanding of others. Although the task involves a partner, these specific contrasts do not specifically measure representations of others’ actions, traits, emotions, or mental states required by the "perception_others" construct, so they do not meet the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult participants (trained dancers); group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrasts reported with FDR correction; task is a dyadic joint-action (social interaction) and the contrast (self-initiated vs externally-triggered / leader vs follower; or partnered vs non-partnered in the table) indexes social interaction/agency processes relevant to social processing. Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult participants and is not an ROI/ connectivity/ between-group analysis. The partnered versus solo contrast indexes dyadic joint action with bimanual physical contact, i.e., exchange of socially relevant non-verbal (non‑facial) signals (coordination/cooperation), which falls under the Social Communication construct (production/reception of non‑facial communication).

This is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (partnered > solo), comparing social/partnered interaction vs non-partnered movement. The task indexes cooperative, physically coupled joint action (partnering), which falls under affiliation/social bonding processes (cooperation/positive social interaction). It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast '[Leading + Solo + Mutual + Alone] > Following' explicitly indexes self-initiation/agency (self-initiated vs externally-triggered). The study used healthy adult dancers, reports whole-brain voxelwise peak coordinates (group-level map, FDR-corrected), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the perception_self inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (Leading > Solo) from healthy adult participants performing a joint improvisation task involving real-time interpersonal coordination. The contrast isolates a social interaction condition (leading in partnered action) versus a non-social solo condition, so it probes social processing (joint action/interaction). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast from healthy adults, the reported contrasts (improvised vs non‑improvised; self‑initiated vs externally‑triggered) probe motor planning/ improvisation and self‑initiation rather than the perception or understanding of others. The contrasts do not explicitly measure action perception or mentalizing about another person's states (they index motor/control processes in a joint-action task), so they do not meet the "perception_others" construct.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (Leading > Solo) indexes joint motor improvisation and role-based motor planning/self-orientation rather than measures of affiliation or attachment. The task involves dyadic joint action with an experimenter (not paradigms assessing close relationships, bonding, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation framed as attachment, etc.), so it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation/attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (Leading > Solo) in healthy adult participants assessing joint improvised action with physical contact. Leading in this paradigm indexes communicative, movement-based coordination (production of non-facial social communication) during cooperative joint action, so it meets the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

Meets inclusion criteria: healthy adult sample, group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrast (Talairach coords, FDR-corrected), not an ROI/connectivity or between-group comparison. The Leading > Solo contrast probes role-related self-oriented processes (agency/self-monitoring)—the study explicitly describes Leading as associated with self-orientation—so it fits the Perception/Understanding of Self (agency) construct.

The analysis reports AEON responses to force during action execution/observation (a motor/effort task), not a task or contrast measuring affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a group-level whole-brain effect in healthy adults, it does not meet the content requirement for affiliation/attachment.

The analysis reports group-level, voxelwise AEON (action execution–observation network) main-effect activations for an action observation task (subjects watched others perform a squeeze task). This is a whole-brain univariate task contrast in healthy adult participants and probes perception/understanding of others (social processing), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast in healthy adult participants contrasting a partnered joint-improvisation role (Leading) with Solo. The task involves cooperative joint action with a partner (action perception / social interaction), so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (particularly action-perception/cooperation). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although the analysis involves action observation in healthy adults and appears to be a whole-brain task-evoked contrast, it does not probe social communication per the defined construct. The task measures observation/execution of motor effort (mirror/AEON responses), not exchange or reception/production of socially communicative signals (facial or non‑facial communication, cooperation/competition, kinship, etc.). Therefore it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain task contrast, the reported analysis tests action execution/observation and force-related BOLD responses (AEON) rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency judgments. It does not operationalize a Perception/Understanding-of-Self task or contrast (e.g., self vs other, agency attribution), so it does not meet the construct criteria.

The reported analysis tests force-related BOLD responses during action execution/observation (a motor/effort task), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a healthy-group, whole-brain map, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level univariate task fMRI analysis in a healthy adult sample examining action observation (AO) within an action execution–observation network. The AO condition probes Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others). The reported map appears to be a whole-brain main effect/conjunction (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis tests force-related BOLD responses during action execution and observation (a squeeze-ball task assessing effort/mirroring), not a task or contrast measuring social communication (receptive/productive facial or non-facial communication). Although the sample and whole-brain analysis criteria appear met, the task does not probe social-communication constructs or relevant contrasts, so it should be excluded.
