The contrast probes a social context manipulation (viewing with a friend vs alone), which falls under Perception/Understanding of Others (social perception/target-related processing similar to examples like Loved one vs Stranger). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-subject, whole-brain task contrast probing social sharing with a friend (shared vs unshared) across emotional valence, which directly measures affiliation/attachment-related processing in healthy adult participants. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group (patient vs control) analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast on healthy adults, the manipulation indexes social sharing/co-experience (awareness that a friend is concurrently viewing) rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behaviors. The task involved no interaction or communicative signals, so it does not meet the definition of Social Communication.

The contrast indexes social sharing/affiliation and valence effects (shared vs unshared for negative vs positive pictures), i.e. social/reward processing, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a within-subject whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, it does not target Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (shared > unshared viewing) in a healthy adult sample examining social sharing/affiliation. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and directly indexes social processing.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults comparing viewing pictures when shared with a friend versus alone (an interaction of valence x sharedness). The task measures social interaction / perception of others (social sharing with a friend), and the contrast is not a between-group or ROI/ connectivity analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants comparing viewing with a friend (shared) versus alone (unshared). The task manipulates social sharing with a friend (an affiliation/attachment-related manipulation), and the contrast indexes affiliation-related neural responses, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (shared vs unshared picture viewing) indexes social presence/affiliation without any exchange or communicative behavior. The annotation requires tasks that measure social communication (receptive or productive facial/non‑facial communication or analogous social-exchange scenarios). Because participants did not communicate or receive communicative signals, this does not meet the "social_communication" construct.

The contrast (shared > unshared) indexes social sharing/affiliation effects during picture viewing (reward/social context), not processes of self‑perception, self‑knowledge, or agency. Although it is a whole‑brain group contrast on healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of the Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a group-level, within-controls whole-brain contrast (dynamic > static facial expressions) indexing perception/reception of facial communication. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, and it comes from the healthy control group, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast (dynamic vs static facial expressions) probes general emotion/social-perceptual processing, not affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although the row appears to report the control group, the task does not target attachment/affiliative constructs, so it does not meet the "affiliation_attachment" inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (dynamic > static facial expressions) reported for the healthy control group. The task is social (perception of others' facial expressions), so it meets the sample, whole-brain, task-evoked, and social-processing inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion rules.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain group comparison in healthy adults, it manipulates social context (viewing pictures together vs alone) rather than requiring participants to perceive, infer, or reason about another person's emotional states, traits, or intentions. The task indexes social sharing/affiliative modulation of experience (reward) rather than Perception and Understanding of Others, so it does not meet the construct inclusion criteria.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast from the healthy/control group (dynamic > static faces), the task probes perception of others' facial expressions (face/emotion perception), not Perception and Understanding of Self (self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or social comparison). Therefore it does not meet the domain requirement for the "perception_self" annotation.

This is a within-group, whole-brain contrast (dynamic vs static facial expressions) reported for the healthy control group, indexing perception/understanding of others' emotional facial expressions. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast (dynamic vs. static facial expressions in an ASD study) does not target affiliation/attachment processes (it tests basic emotion/dynamic face processing), and the sample/analysis involves a clinical group comparison rather than a whole‑brain map from healthy adults only. Therefore it fails the task and sample inclusion criteria.

The analysis comes from a study of individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and likely reflects patient (or mixed patient/control) data (the analysis name is 'ASD' and the study compares ASD vs controls). Inclusion requires a whole-brain group-level map from healthy adults only. Although the task (dynamic vs static facial expressions) is social, the sample criterion is not met, so it must be excluded.

The contrast comes from a study comparing individuals with ASD and matched controls and the analysis description does not specify that the reported whole‑brain map is from the healthy/control group alone. Inclusion requires a group‑level, whole‑brain map from healthy adults only (not clinical or mixed samples or between‑group contrasts). Therefore this analysis does not meet the sample criterion.

The contrast reflects perception of others' dynamic vs static facial expressions in a study including ASD patients and controls (not a healthy-only group) and does not target self-related processes (self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge). Therefore it fails the sample and task/content inclusion criteria for perception_self.

The reported analysis is a group × condition interaction comparing ASD and control participants (a between-group contrast involving a clinical group). Inclusion requires a whole-brain, group-level univariate map from healthy adults only (or contrasts within the healthy/control group). Although the task is social (dynamic vs. static facial expressions), this analysis is a between-group interaction and therefore excluded.

This analysis reports a group × presentation-condition interaction (ASD vs controls; dynamic vs static faces). It is a between-group interaction involving a clinical group rather than a within-group whole-brain contrast from healthy adults, so it fails the inclusion criteria (between-group contrasts/interactions are excluded).

This analysis reports a group × presentation interaction from a mixed sample (ASD vs typically developing controls) rather than a within-group, healthy-adult whole-brain contrast. Inclusion requires group-level, univariate whole-brain maps from healthy adults only and tasks/contrasts specifically indexing affiliation/attachment. This is a between-group interaction in a clinical study of emotion/dynamic vs static faces (not clearly an affiliation/attachment contrast), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (dynamic vs static facial expressions) taps Perception/Understanding of Others, but the study includes an ASD clinical group and the extract does not specify that the reported map is a group-level whole-brain result from the healthy/control participants alone. Inclusion requires a healthy adult group map (not clinical or between-group contrasts). Because the sample/contrast origin is unclear and likely involves a clinical comparison, this analysis should be excluded.

This analysis reports a group × condition interaction involving an ASD clinical group (comparison between ASD and controls) rather than a within-group, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adults. The inclusion rules exclude between-group contrasts/interactions and clinical/special-group comparisons, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' criteria.

The entry describes regions of interest used for real-time classification (ROI-based analysis), not a group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked voxelwise map. ROI analyses are excluded by the criteria, so this should not be included.

The reported analysis is a group × condition interaction comparing individuals with ASD and matched controls (clinical vs healthy groups). Inclusion requires a within-group, whole-brain contrast from healthy adults only. Between-group contrasts/interactions (or analyses including a clinical group) are explicitly excluded.

This analysis is an ROI-based real-time pattern classification (regions of interest used for online classification in an ultimatum game). It is not a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task map as required, and ROI/multivariate classification analyses are explicitly excluded.

This entry describes regions of interest used for real-time classification (ROI definition), not a group-level voxelwise whole-brain univariate statistical contrast. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria despite the task being a social interaction.

The entry describes regions-of-interest used for real-time pattern classification (ROI/multivariate approach), not a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast. ROI/multivariate analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria, so this analysis does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion requirements.

This analysis describes regions of interest (LPFC) used for real-time pattern classification (ROI-based, multivariate) rather than a group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked univariate contrast. ROI/classification analyses do not meet the whole-brain univariate inclusion criterion for the perception_others annotation.

This entry describes regions of interest used for real-time pattern classification (ROI-based, multivariate) rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise statistical map. The annotation requires whole-brain group univariate task-evoked contrasts; ROI/multivariate analyses are excluded.

This entry describes a region-of-interest (anterior insula) used for real-time pattern classification rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map. ROI/classification analyses are excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included.

This entry describes regions of interest used for real-time pattern classification (an ROI analysis), not a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise task-evoked contrast. ROI/multivariate real-time classification analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria, so it does not meet the 'whole-brain evidence' inclusion requirement.

This entry describes regions of interest used for real-time classification (ROI / multivariate analysis), not a group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrast. ROI/multivariate classification analyses do not meet the inclusion criterion for whole-brain, group-level univariate maps, so it must be excluded.

This entry describes a region-of-interest (Occipital Cortex) used for real-time pattern classification rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. ROI/multivariate classification analyses do not meet the whole-brain univariate inclusion criterion, so it should be excluded.

This entry reports regions of interest used for real-time multivariate classification (ROI-based analysis) rather than a group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical map. The inclusion criteria require a whole-brain univariate group map; ROI/multivariate classification analyses are explicitly excluded.

This entry describes regions-of-interest (occipital cortex) used for real-time pattern classification (ROI-based/multivariate) rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise contrast measuring affiliation/attachment. ROI/multivariate/real-time classification analyses do not meet the whole-brain univariate inclusion criteria, so it is excluded.

This entry describes regions of interest used for real-time classification (ROI analysis), not a group-level whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise contrast. ROI analyses are excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included.

This entry lists Regions of Interest used for real-time pattern classification (Occipital Cortex ROIs). It is an ROI-based/multivariate classification element rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked voxelwise map. ROI and classification analyses are excluded by the criteria.

This analysis describes regions-of-interest used for real-time pattern classification (Occipital Cortex ROI). It is an ROI/multivariate/classification analysis rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked voxelwise contrast in healthy adults, so it fails the whole-brain/univariate inclusion criterion and meets the ROI exclusion criterion.

This entry reports discriminative volumes from a linear SVM (multivariate classification) / ROI selection for real‑time classification rather than a group‑level, univariate whole‑brain task activation contrast. It therefore does not meet the requirement for a voxelwise group whole‑brain task map and falls under excluded ROI/multivariate classification analyses.

This analysis reports discriminative volumes from a linear SVM (offline MVPA / classifier weights) and/or ROIs used for real-time classification, not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map. Although the task is social (ultimatum game) and participants are healthy, the result type (multivariate classifier weights/ROI-based) does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring whole-brain univariate voxelwise group maps.

This analysis reports discriminative volumes from a linear SVM (multivariate classification) and ROIs used for real-time classification, not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise contrast. Although the study used healthy adults and a social decision task (ultimatum game), the reported results are MVPA/ROI-based rather than a whole-brain univariate map, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

This is an MVPA/classification result (SVM discriminative volumes / weight map / ROIs used for real-time classification), not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast. It therefore fails the requirement for a voxelwise univariate map and is essentially ROI/MVPA-based, so it should be excluded.

This analysis is an ROI-based multivariate/classification (real-time pattern classification of 70:30 vs 80:20 offers) rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrast generalizable to healthy adults. The table caption explicitly lists regions of interest, and the reported analysis is classification-based, both of which fall under the exclusion criteria.

This analysis is an ROI-based real-time classification (70:30 vs 80:20 offers) from an ultimatum-game study using pattern classification. It is not a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast measuring affiliation/attachment; ROI/MVPA/real-time classification analyses are excluded by the criteria.

The reported analysis is an ROI-based real-time multivariate classification (Table lists regions of interest used for classification of offer types). Although the task (ultimatum game) involves social interaction and the sample are healthy adults, this is not a group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrast as required. ROI/multivariate classification analyses are explicitly excluded.

This analysis is an ROI-based real-time multivariate classification (regions of interest used to classify 70:30 vs 80:20 offers) rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level univariate maps in healthy adults measuring Perception/Understanding of Self; ROI/multivariate classification analyses are explicitly excluded.

This analysis reports discriminative volumes from a linear SVM (offline MVPA) and served to define ROIs for real-time classification. It is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adults, and therefore fails the whole-brain/univariate and ROI exclusion criteria.

This analysis describes real-time MVPA/classification of offer types using predefined regions of interest (table lists ROIs). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map in healthy adults. Because this is an ROI-based multivariate/classification analysis (not a whole-brain univariate group contrast), it should be excluded.

This analysis describes ROI-based real-time/multivariate classification of offer types (and the table lists regions of interest). It is not a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrast generalizable to healthy adults, and ROI/MVPA classification analyses are excluded by the criteria.

This entry reports ROI-based real-time/multivariate classification of offer types (regions of interest used in classification) rather than a group-level whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task contrast. Although the task (ultimatum game) involves social decision-making in healthy adults, the analysis is ROI/multivariate classification and therefore fails the required whole-brain univariate inclusion criterion.

This analysis is an ROI-based multivariate real-time classification of offer types in an ultimatum game, not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast. It therefore fails the “whole-brain evidence” requirement and also falls under the ROI/decoding exclusion. Additionally, the contrast (offer types in an economic negotiation) does not clearly map onto affiliation/attachment measures (e.g., close relationships or attachment paradigms).

This analysis is an ROI-based real-time multivariate classification (regions of interest used to classify offer types) from an ultimatum-game decision task. It is not a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast measuring Perception/Understanding of Self, so it fails the whole-brain (and ROI/multivariate) inclusion requirements and does not target the specified self-perception construct.

This analysis is an ROI-based multivariate/real-time classification (regions of interest used to classify 50:50 vs 65:35 offers), not a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise task map. It therefore fails the 'whole-brain evidence' requirement (and ROI analyses are explicitly excluded), so it should not be included in the perception_others annotation.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (ToM > R) indexing Theory-of-Mind/mentalization, which clearly falls under social processing (perception/understanding of others). The reported analysis uses whole-brain voxelwise thresholds and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast. The study context implies a healthy adult task sample. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a Theory-of-Mind (ToM > R) whole-brain mentalizing analysis, not a task or contrast indexing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a group-level whole-brain contrast, it does not measure affiliation/attachment content, so it fails the task-domain inclusion criterion.

The contrast is a Theory-of-Mind (ToM > R) whole-brain analysis targeting attribution of mental states to others, not processes of self-perception/self-knowledge. Although it meets sample and whole-brain requirements, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

This is a VOI/ROI-based Bayesian comparison (mPFC vs right pSTG; 15 mm radius; averages within volumes), not a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast. ROI/VOI analyses are excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included despite being a social (ToM) task in healthy adults.

The contrast 'ToM > R' is a whole-brain, group-level task-evoked univariate analysis targeting Theory of Mind (understanding others' mental states), which fits the 'Understanding Mental States' subconstruct of perception_others. The table caption indicates a voxelwise whole-brain contrast (not an ROI or connectivity analysis) and does not describe a between-group or clinical comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a VOI/ROI Bayesian comparison (mPFC vs r-pSTG) from a ToM > R contrast, not a group-level whole-brain univariate map. Additionally, the task probes Theory of Mind/mentalization rather than affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation), so it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a Theory-of-Mind (ToM) mentalizing contrast rather than an explicit social-communication task. The annotation target is focused on exchange of socially relevant information (receptive/productive facial or non‑facial communication), and the provided analysis description does not indicate a task or contrast that clearly measures social communication per the specified subconstructs. In addition, participant sample details (healthy adults only) are not specified. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria for the "social_communication" annotation.

This is an ROI/volume-of-interest Bayesian comparison (mPFC vs right pSTG) using averaged BOLD within a sphere, not a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise map. ROI analyses are excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included.

This is an ROI/VOI Bayesian comparison (mPFC vs r-pSTS) rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. Although it concerns a ToM (Perception/Understanding of Others) contrast in presumably healthy adults, it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence and thus must be excluded per the ROI exclusion criterion.

This is an ROI/VOI Bayesian analysis (mean BOLD within 15 mm volumes) comparing mPFC and right pSTG for a ToM > R contrast. It is not a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation map as required, and the contrast reflects Theory-of-Mind (mentalizing about others) rather than Perception/Understanding of the Self. Therefore it fails the whole-brain and task-domain inclusion criteria.

Healthy sample (late adolescents, 18–22, non-clinical) performing an observation task of others' actions (social/perception of others). The reported result (insula activation mediating age–extraversion) comes from task-evoked brain activation (table caption indicates brain regions mediating associations), not an ROI/seed/connectivity or between-group contrast, so it meets the whole-brain, task-based social processing inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis reflects observation of risk-taking versus safe hand actions and correlations/mediation with age and personality (e.g., extraversion/insula). This is an action-observation/emotion/personality task, not a task that measures social-communication (no exchange of socially relevant information, facial or non‑facial communicative reception/production, or contrasts like cooperation/kinship). Therefore it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

The analysis comes from a task in which participants observed risk-taking vs safe hand actions (risk perception), not a task probing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the contrast measure Affiliation and Attachment.

The reported analysis links insula activation during observation of risk-taking vs safe actions to age and extraversion, but the imaging task is passive observation of others' actions rather than an explicit task probing self‑perception/self‑knowledge (e.g., self-evaluation, social comparison, kinship scenarios). Although extraversion is a self-trait, the contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the inclusion criteria, so it should be excluded.

The fMRI task involved observing risk-taking versus safe hand actions and the reported analysis links age/extraversion to brain activation (insula mediation). This is not a task or contrast measuring affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger), so it fails the domain-specific inclusion criterion despite being a whole-brain analysis in healthy participants.

The reported analysis is a mediation (insula activation mediating age–extraversion) rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast. This is a secondary/region-specific statistical test (likely ROI/extracted activation) and not a voxelwise task-evoked map generalizable as a main effect or within-group contrast, so it fails the 'whole-brain evidence' inclusion criterion despite the task involving action observation.

The analysis examines brain regions (insula, MTG, etc.) mediating the relationship between age and extraversion during observation of risk-taking actions — a task involving perception/understanding of others’ actions and social/emotional processing. The sample is healthy late-adolescents (18–22), the reported results are group-level task-evoked voxelwise effects (whole-brain mediation identifying regions), and the analysis is univariate rather than ROI or connectivity-based. Therefore it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria. (Assumes the mediation was performed voxelwise/whole-brain as indicated by the table caption.)

Although the sample are healthy young adults and the analysis appears to be a whole-brain task-evoked mediation, the task (observation of risk-taking vs safe hand actions) and the reported contrast/mediation (insula mediating age–extraversion) do not index Social Communication as defined (exchange of socially relevant information / facial or non‑facial communicative reception/production). Therefore it does not meet the Social_Communication inclusion criteria.

Exclude. Although the sample is healthy adults, the reported analysis is a mediation linking age and an extraversion trait to insula activation during observation of risk-taking actions — not a task or contrast that measures Perception/Understanding of the Self. Moreover the result is a region-specific mediation (insula) rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate task contrast generalizable to healthy adults. Thus it does not meet the task and whole-brain inclusion criteria for "perception_self."

The task involves observing risk-taking versus safe hand actions and examines age-related changes in anxiety/extraversion (and mediation by insula). This is not a task probing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the requirement that the analysis measures affiliation and attachment.

The analysis tests neural responses during observation of others' hand actions (action perception, a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others) in a healthy late-adolescent sample. The reported age/extraversion correlations and mediation (insula mediating age → extraversion) come from group-level task-evoked voxelwise results (whole-brain contrasts/regressions) rather than ROI/connectivity or between-group comparisons, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis comes from an action-observation task (viewing risky vs safe hand movements) and examines age/psychological correlates of activation. This is not a social communication task/contrast (no exchange of socially relevant communicative signals such as facial or verbal/interactive scenarios), so it fails the content requirement for the social_communication annotation despite being a whole-brain, healthy-sample analysis.

The analysis reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task-evoked effects (correlations/mediation between age/psychological measures and activation) in a healthy sample of late adolescents (ages 18+). The fMRI task involved observing others' actions (risk-taking vs safe actions), which falls under social processing (perception/understanding of others). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The fMRI contrast involves passive observation of risk-taking versus safe hand actions and correlations with trait measures (age, anxiety, extraversion). Although psychological traits are self-report, the task does not probe self-perception, self-knowledge, agency, or explicit self-evaluative processes (e.g., social comparison, kinship, loved-one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the "Perception and Understanding of Self" task requirement.

This is a group-level, voxelwise task analysis in healthy late-adolescents (ages 18+) during observation of others' actions (risk-taking vs safe), i.e. Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others). The reported voxelwise correlations/mediation with age and psychological measures are whole-brain, within-group effects, and not ROI/seed/connectivity or between-group contrasts — so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis does not probe affiliation/attachment. It examines neural responses to observed risk-taking actions and mediation of the relationship between age and extraversion/anxiety, not an affiliation/attachment task or contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation, kinship). Therefore it fails the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

The analysis reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked activations (correlations/mediation between age/extraversion and neural activation) from a healthy sample of late adolescents (age range 18–22), during observation of others' actions (risk-taking vs safe), which is a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria. (Note: participants are late adolescents but are adults by age ≥18.)

Although the study tested healthy late-adolescents (18–22) during an action-observation task, the reported analysis is a mediation linking age and extraversion via insula activation rather than a standard group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast measuring Social Communication. The task (observing risk-taking vs safe hand actions) does not operationalize Social Communication per the annotation definition, and the mediation analysis is not a simple univariate task contrast suitable for inclusion.

The reported analysis indexes brain activation correlating with age and extraversion during observation of risk-taking vs safe actions and reports a mediation (insula mediating age→extraversion). The task and contrasts assess response to observed actions, not Perception/Understanding of the Self (self-knowledge or agency) as required. Although the sample is healthy and whole-brain correlations/mediation are reported, the experiment does not probe self-related processing, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast (CSL > TIC) from healthy adult participants measuring perception/evaluation of laughter, a social-communication process. It is not an ROI or connectivity analysis nor a between-group comparison, so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

The contrast concerns perception/evaluation of different laughter types (complex social vs tickling) rather than a task probing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, attachment measures). Although it appears to be a healthy-group, whole-brain task contrast, the task does not specifically measure affiliation or attachment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares complex social laughter (CSL) versus tickling laughter (TIC) in a task-based fMRI study of healthy adults, indexing perception/reception of non‑facial social communication (vocal laughter). The result is a group-level whole-brain univariate activation contrast (not ROI or connectivity and not a between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

CSL>TIC is a within-group task contrast comparing complex social laughter versus tickling laughter in a healthy sample, reflecting perception/processing of others' social signals (socio-relational/mental state information). The result is a task-evoked, group-level hemodynamic activation contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

The CSL > TIC contrast indexes perception of different types of others' laughter (complex social vs tickling) and associated social/mentalizing processing, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or judgments about the self. Thus it does not meet the ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ task/content criterion.

The analysis derives from a task in which participants observed others' hand actions (action perception, a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others), the sample is healthy late adolescents (ages 18–22), and the reported effects (age/extraversion correlations and insula mediation) arise from task-evoked neural activation rather than a between-group, connectivity, or purely ROI-only analysis. Therefore it meets the perception_others criteria. (Note: mediation was reported on task-evoked activation; if that mediation were solely on an a priori ROI with no whole-brain map, it would be grounds for exclusion.)

TIC>CSL is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast comparing tickling versus complex social laughter in a healthy adult sample, indexing perception/processing of social signals (laughter). It is whole-brain activation (not ROI or connectivity) and therefore meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, task-evoked contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (tickling laughter vs complex social laughter) probes acoustic/social-type processing and mentalizing about laughter, not measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, bonding or attachment scales). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

TIC>CSL is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast comparing tickling laughter to complex social laughter in a healthy adult sample, reported as differential hemodynamic activation (whole-brain/univariate). It probes perception/reception of non‑facial social vocal communication (laughter), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria (reception of non-facial communication) and does not appear to be an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The TIC>CSL contrast compares perception of tickling vs complex social laughter (others' vocalizations). Although likely a whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adults, it probes social perception of others' laughter, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self required for the “perception_self” category. Therefore it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (TIC>CSL) in a healthy adult sample comparing types of social laughter. The contrast indexes processing of socially relevant vocal signals (laughter) and thus taps perception/understanding of others' emotional/social states. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (hemodynamic activation) in a healthy adult sample probing perception/evaluation of laughter types — an explicitly social signal. It is a whole-brain univariate activation contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), and thus meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

The contrast concerns perception/evaluation of different laughter types (complex social vs tickling) rather than an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a healthy sample and whole-brain task, the paradigm does not specifically measure affiliation or attachment, so it fails the task/contrast inclusion criteria.

CAT>COU appears to be a within-group task contrast comparing explicit categorization/evaluation of laughter versus a control/counting condition in a healthy adult sample. The contrast indexes perception/evaluation of non‑facial social vocal signals (laughter), which falls under Reception of Non‑Facial Communication. It is reported as a task-evoked hemodynamic activation contrast (not an ROI, seed/connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the whole-brain univariate inclusion criteria.

CAT>COU contrasts explicit evaluation (categorization) of laughter types versus a control/counting condition, reflecting task-evoked, group-level whole-brain activation to social vocalizations. This probes perception/understanding of others' social/emotional signals (understanding mental states) in healthy adults and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (CAT>COU) pertains to perception/evaluation of different laughter types (social signals from others), not to self-related processing (agency or self-knowledge). The study focuses on perception of others' laughter and connectivity differences rather than tasks that require awareness, judgment, or comparison of the self, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' task requirement.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate fMRI activation analysis (conjunction of conditions) measuring neural responses to perception/evaluation of laughter (a social stimulus) in a non-clinical sample. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, and therefore meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports group-level hemodynamic activation for perception/evaluation of different laughter types (complex social vs. tickling) in healthy adults — an auditory social signal (reception of non-facial communication). It is a univariate task-evoked contrast/conjunction reported as regions (i.e., whole-brain activation), not an ROI or connectivity or between-group comparison, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults, the task probes perception/evaluation of different laughter types (complex social vs tickling) and attention (evaluation vs counting). It does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, bonding) or an affiliation-related task contrast, so it fails the content/domain inclusion criterion.

The contrast reflects perception/evaluation of others' laughter types (social signal processing), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or self-related judgments. Although it appears to be a whole-brain task-evoked group analysis in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as required.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) from a healthy adult sample engaging in real-time eye contact — a clear social interaction task probing perception/understanding of others. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a task-evoked, group-level fMRI contrast (a conjunction of within-group conditions) reporting common hemodynamic activation during perception/explicit evaluation of complex social and tickling laughter. It targets perception of social signals (evaluation of others' affect/intent), fits the "Perception and Understanding of Others" construct, and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. The sample is described in the study as typical healthy participants, so it meets the sample requirement.

This is a within-group, whole‑brain univariate contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) in healthy adult participants, probing real-time eye contact—a form of social communication (production/reception of facial/gaze behavior). It is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) in healthy adult participants assessing on-line mutual eye-gaze (perception of another's actions/attention). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore fits the Perception and Understanding of Others category (action/animacy perception).

Although the study involves healthy adults and a social eye-contact task, this specific analysis reports enhanced effective connectivity from the ACC (a seed-based/effective connectivity measure). The inclusion criteria require group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts; seed-based/effective connectivity analyses are explicitly excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (LIVE > REPLAY), the task probes mutual eye-gaze and perceptual-motor interaction rather than an affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/relationship measures). The contrast does not explicitly measure attachment or affiliation constructs, so it does not meet the task-domain inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) in healthy adult participants and is not an ROI or connectivity analysis. The task probes real-time mutual eye contact and the authors interpret ACC/AIC activation as reflecting self-awareness/self-monitoring (limbic mirror system), so it maps onto Perception and Understanding of Self.

The analysis is an effective connectivity/seed-based analysis (“enhanced effective connectivity from the ACC in the LIVE condition”), which falls under the exclusion criteria (seed/effective connectivity). Although the task involves social eye contact in healthy adults, the analysis type is not a whole-brain univariate task-evoked voxelwise contrast and therefore should be excluded.

The reported analysis is an effective connectivity (seed-based) result—'enhanced effective connectivity from the ACC'—which falls under the exclusion criterion (seed/effective connectivity analyses). Although the sample and task are appropriate, this is not a group-level univariate whole-brain activation contrast required for the perception_self annotation.

The reported analysis is an effective-connectivity/seed-based directional connectivity analysis (enhanced effective connectivity from the ACC / multivariate autoregression), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria (seed-based/effective connectivity analyses are not eligible), so it should not be included despite involving healthy adults and a social eye-contact task.

The analysis reports enhanced effective connectivity from the ACC (seed/effective-connectivity result). Per the exclusion rules, seed-based/effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI/DCM) are not eligible. It is also not a group-level univariate whole-brain task activation map, so it fails the whole-brain evidence requirement even though the sample is healthy.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (LIVE vs REPLAY) conducted in healthy adult participants. The task probes on-line mutual eye-gaze, a social/affiliative cue involving attention to another person and real-time interaction, which falls under affiliation/attachment (detection of and attention to social cues and positive social interaction). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the sample (healthy adults) and task (live eye contact) are social and group-level, the analysis is described as measuring "interbrain synchronization" (hyperscanning/synchrony between brains) rather than a univariate, task-evoked whole‑brain activation contrast. That makes it a connectivity/synchronization-type analysis, which falls outside the inclusion requirement for univariate whole‑brain task-activation maps (and is excluded by the connectivity/seed‑based/effective‑connectivity exclusion criteria).

The analysis is described as identifying regions with enhanced interbrain synchronization (a connectivity/inter-subject synchronization measure) for LIVE vs REPLAY. Inclusion requires a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast. Connectivity/inter-brain synchronization analyses fall under the exclusion criteria (connectivity-type analyses), so this does not meet the inclusion requirements despite the task being social (eye contact).

The analysis is described as assessing interbrain synchronization (hyperscanning/connectivity) in LIVE vs REPLAY. The inclusion criteria require a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation contrast; connectivity/interbrain synchronization analyses are excluded. Although the study used healthy adults and discusses self-related regions, this specific analysis is a connectivity measure and therefore should not be included.

The analysis title describes "interbrain synchronization" (a hyperscanning/connectivity-type measure) rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast. Although the study concerns social perception (eye contact) in healthy adults, the inclusion criteria require a voxelwise univariate activation map; connectivity/interbrain synchronization analyses are excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Pain > no pain) in healthy adult participants performing an empathy-for-pain task (viewing others' pain vs control), which probes social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults, the task probes empathy for others' pain (needles vs Q‑tips) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation). It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assess affiliation and attachment.

This contrast (pain > no pain viewing needles vs q-tips) probes empathy for others' pain (perception of others), not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it fails the task-content inclusion criterion.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task probes empathy for others' pain (passive viewing of needle vs q‑tip stimuli) rather than social communication as defined (exchange of socially relevant information, facial/non‑facial communicative signals or communication-focused tasks). Therefore it does not meet the annotation's Social_Communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Pain > No pain) from healthy adult participants viewing others in pain (needles vs Q-tips), which directly measures perception/understanding of others' emotional/physical state (empathy for pain). It is not an ROI or connectivity analysis nor a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (pain vs baseline/no-pain) in a sample of healthy young and older adults performing an empathy-for-pain task. The contrast measures perception/understanding of others' pain (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes empathy for pain (pain vs no-pain pictures), not affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although the sample is healthy and the map appears to be a whole-brain task contrast, the task/contrast does not measure Affiliation and Attachment as defined, so it should be excluded.

Although this is a healthy, whole-brain, within-group pain>no-pain contrast, the task probes empathy for observed pain (images of hands being pricked) rather than social communication or exchange of socially relevant signals (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communicative behaviors). Therefore it does not meet the 'social_communication' construct criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrast (pain > no-pain/baseline) in healthy adult participants viewing others in pain (an empathy for pain paradigm). It measures perception/understanding of others' emotional states, is not an ROI or connectivity analysis, and is not a between-group contrast — therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This contrast indexes empathy for others' pain (viewing needles vs Q‑tips) rather than processes of self-perception/self‑knowledge or agency. Although it is a healthy, whole‑brain group contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

The reported analysis is a between-group contrast (older > young) for pain>no pain. The inclusion criteria require within-group, whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults; between-group contrasts/subgroup comparisons are explicitly excluded.

Excluded. The contrast is a between-group comparison (older > young for pain>no pain), which violates the exclusion criteria, and the task probes empathy for pain (pain vs no-pain), not affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation).

This analysis is a between-group contrast (older > young for pain > no pain), which falls under the exclusion criteria (between-group contrasts/interactions). In addition, the task probes empathy for pain (observing painful vs non-painful touch), which does not clearly map onto the defined Social Communication construct. Therefore it should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (older > young for pain > no pain), which falls under the exclusion criterion for subgroup vs subgroup comparisons. In addition, the contrast indexes empathy for others (pain vs no pain), not Perception/Understanding of the Self. Therefore it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

This analysis is a between-group contrast (young > older) for pain>baseline. Although the task (empathy for pain) is social, the inclusion rules exclude subgroup/between-group contrasts, so it should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (older > young for pain > no pain). Although the task assesses empathy for others (fits the Perception/Understanding of Others domain), the inclusion rules exclude between-group contrasts/subgroup comparisons, so this analysis should not be included.

This analysis is a between-group contrast (young > older) of an empathy-for-pain task. Between-group contrasts are excluded by the criteria, and the task/contrast probes empathy for others' pain rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation_attachment inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (young > older) for a pain (others' pain) condition. The inclusion criteria require within-group, whole-brain task contrasts measuring Perception/Understanding of the Self; the current analysis is both a between-group comparison (explicitly excluded) and concerns empathy for others' pain rather than self-related perception/knowledge.

This is a between-group contrast (young > older for pain>baseline). Although the task probes perception/understanding of others' pain, the inclusion rules exclude between-group contrasts/interactions; therefore this analysis should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (young > older for pain > baseline), which violates the exclusion criterion against subgroup/between-group contrasts. In addition, the task probes empathic response to pain rather than exchange of social-communication signals (facial/non‑facial communicative reception/production), so it does not meet the "social_communication" construct.

The reported analysis is a between-group contrast (older > young for pain>baseline). Although the task probes social processing (empathy for others' pain) and is whole-brain, the inclusion rules explicitly exclude between-group contrasts/interactions, so this analysis should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (older > young) from an empathy-for-pain task, not a measure of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Between-group contrasts are excluded and the task does not target affiliation/attachment, so it should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (older > young for pain>baseline). The inclusion rules require group-level, within-group whole-brain maps generalizable to healthy adults; between-group contrasts or interactions are explicitly excluded. Additionally, the task probes empathy for pain rather than a Social Communication paradigm.

This is a between-group contrast (older > young for pain>baseline), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. In addition, the task probes empathy for others' pain (perception of others), not perception/understanding of the self, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct.

The contrast is a between-group comparison (older > young for pain>baseline). Although the task probes empathy for others' pain (which would map to Perception/Understanding of Others), the annotation criteria exclude between-group contrasts/subgroup comparisons, so this analysis should not be included.

This analysis probes empathy for pain (needles vs Q-tips), not affiliation/attachment tasks, and reports an age group × sleep condition interaction (a between-group contrast). It therefore does not meet the task domain requirement and is excluded by the between-group/interaction exclusion criterion.

This is an interaction contrast (age group × sleep condition), i.e. a between-group interaction, which falls under the exclusion criteria. Although the task (empathy for others' pain) targets social processing and the data are whole-brain group maps, between-group contrasts/interactions are explicitly excluded.

This analysis is an interaction contrast (age group * sleep condition) for pain>baseline from an empathy-for-pain task. It represents a between-group interaction (excluded per criteria) and the task probes empathic pain responses rather than social communication (exchange of socially relevant information / facial/non‑facial communication). Therefore it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-by-condition interaction contrast (age group * sleep condition) from an empathy-for-pain task. The exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts/interactions, and the task probes empathy for others' pain (not Perception/Understanding of the Self). Therefore it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group GLM on healthy adults, the task/contrast indexes suspense and predictive/social cognition during reading, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria for 'affiliation_attachment'.

This is an interaction contrast (age group × sleep condition) for pain>baseline, i.e. a between-group interaction across age subgroups. The exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts or interactions, so it should not be included despite using an empathy-for-pain task in healthy adults.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM contrast (reading > rating) in a healthy adult sample. The task (reading a suspenseful literary text) invokes narrative-based social cognition/predictive inference (e.g., understanding characters’ minds), and the authors explicitly link activations (medial frontal, temporo-parietal, posterior temporal) to social cognition. Thus it meets the social processing inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level analysis on healthy adults, the task probes suspense and predictive/social-cognitive processes during literary reading rather than an exchange of social information or an explicit social-communication task (e.g., reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals). The contrast (reading > rating / suspense regressor) does not operationalize Social Communication per the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group GLM on healthy adults, the contrast (reading > rating) and the suspense regressor index narrative-driven suspense/social-cognitive and predictive-inference processes, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or self-monitoring. Therefore it does not meet the ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ task/contrast requirement.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level GLM in healthy adults, the contrast (reading > rating of a suspenseful text) does not explicitly measure Perception and Understanding of Others (e.g., mental state attribution, social comparison, kinship/cooperation contrasts). Activation in regions linked to social cognition does not by itself satisfy the requirement that the task/contrast probe perception/understanding of others. Therefore it should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain group-level fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the task and contrast index suspense/predictive inference from a literary text, not affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, close-relationship, cooperation comparisons). Therefore it does not meet the domain requirement for affiliation_attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain GLM (univariate) analysis in healthy adult participants linking suspense ratings during reading of a literary text to BOLD signal (parametric suspense regressor). The task involves narrative comprehension and engagement with characters/intentions, which taps social cognition/social processing (authors also report activation in social-cognition areas). The analysis is not ROI-based, not connectivity, and not a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level GLM on healthy adults, the contrast (reading > rating and a parametric suspense regressor) indexes suspense/predictive inference during narrative reading, not the exchange or reception/production of socially relevant communicative signals. It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task measure Social Communication (facial or non‑facial communicative processes).

This is a seed-based PPI functional connectivity analysis (modulation of connectivity by suspense), which falls under the exclusion criteria (seed-based/effective connectivity). It is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation contrast required for the 'social_processing_all' annotation.

Although the analysis is a whole‑brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes subjective suspense during narrative reading rather than an explicit measure of perceiving or reasoning about other people's mental states/traits/actions. The task/contrast does not clearly operationalize 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (e.g., ToM, social comparison, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the annotation's content requirement.

This contrast indexes experienced suspense while reading a literary text (an emotional/predictive inference and social-cognition task), not judgments or representations about the self (agency or self-knowledge). Although participants provided subjective suspense ratings, the task does not probe self-related perception/knowledge as defined by the "perception_self" construct, so it should be excluded.

This is a seed-based PPI connectivity analysis (left IFG) examining suspense-modulated functional connectivity — which falls under excluded effective/seed-based connectivity analyses. In addition, the task contrasts suspense in a literary text (not an affiliation/attachment task), so it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria.

This analysis is a seed-based PPI functional connectivity analysis (left IFG seed), which falls under the exclusion criteria (seed-based/effective connectivity). It is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task activation contrast measuring Social Communication, so it should be excluded.

This is a seed-based PPI connectivity analysis (functional connectivity modulated by suspense), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria (seed-based/effective connectivity). It is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast measuring self-perception.

This is a PPI (seed-based functional connectivity) analysis (suspense modulating connectivity with an MFC seed). The exclusion criteria disallow seed-based/effective connectivity analyses; the annotation requires a group-level univariate whole-brain task activation/contrast measuring social processing, which this is not.

This analysis is a seed-based PPI connectivity analysis (functional connectivity), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. Although the task involves social/suspense processing in healthy adults, the analysis type (PPI/seed-based connectivity) disqualifies it from the required whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrast.

This is a PPI seed-based connectivity analysis (modulation of functional connectivity by suspense). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation contrast; the exclusion criteria explicitly rule out seed-based/effective connectivity (e.g., PPI). Therefore it should be excluded.

Excluded: this is a seed-based PPI connectivity analysis (seed-based functional connectivity), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. Additionally, the task manipulates narrative suspense rather than an affiliation/attachment contrast, so it does not measure the target construct.

This is a seed-based PPI functional connectivity analysis (suspense modulating connectivity with an MFC seed), which falls under the exclusion criteria (seed-based/effective connectivity). It is not a group-level whole-brain univariate task contrast measuring perception/understanding of the self, so it should not be included.

This is a whole-brain, group-level random-effects contrast (social interaction vs non-social interaction) from a task that probes perception/interpretation of social interactions in healthy adults. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a seed-based functional connectivity (PPI) analysis (suspense modulating connectivity with an MFC seed). The exclusion criteria explicitly disallow seed-based/effective connectivity analyses; the annotation requires group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts measuring Perception/Understanding of Others. Therefore it should not be included.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast in (presumably) healthy adults (social interaction vs non-social interaction), the task probes general perception of social interactions between agents rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, parental/peer bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/competition). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast specifically measures affiliation and attachment.

This is a whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate contrast (social interaction vs non-social interaction) in presumably healthy adults. The task probes perception of social interactions depicted by point-lights (non-facial/body-language communication), which fits the Social Communication (reception of non-facial communication) construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast isolates brain responses to observed social interactions between two agents (others) versus non-interactions; this probes perception of others/interaction processing, not perception or understanding of the self. Although it is a whole‑brain group contrast on healthy adults, it does not measure self‑related processes, so it fails the task/content inclusion criterion for 'perception_self.'

This is a whole-brain random-effects group contrast (social interaction > non-social interaction) reporting voxelwise activations surviving FDR correction, from a study of observers viewing agent interactions (i.e., perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (campaign vs neutral videos) in healthy adult participants showing greater BOLD in regions (notably STS) associated with empathy/social cognition. The task explicitly probes social processing (empathy/understanding others), and the analysis is not ROI- or connectivity-based nor a between-group comparison.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level univariate comparison in healthy adults, the task probes empathy elicited by traffic-awareness campaign videos rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, bonding). Therefore it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criterion for affiliation_attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, within-subject contrast (campaign vs neutral videos) in healthy adults and is not an ROI or connectivity analysis. The task involves viewing social/empathic scenarios (narrative/video-based social cues), which maps onto reception of social communication (reception of non-facial/social communicative information) and thus fits the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The CV > NV contrast indexes empathic responses to others (campaign vs neutral videos) and social-cognitive processing (STS), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although the sample and analysis appear to be a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the annotation inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (campaign vs neutral videos) in healthy adult participants that targets empathy/social cognition (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This contrast (implicit event simulation vs control) probes situational inference/event simulation, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Although likely a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task does not target Perception and Understanding of Self, so it fails the construct inclusion criteria.

The contrast (Implicit vs Control) comes from an event-simulation task involving object pictures and situational inference, not measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes implicit event simulation (Imp − Control) using object-picture/word matching, not a task probing exchange or reception/production of socially relevant communicative signals. Although the study touches on social cognition (e.g., mentalizing), the reported analysis does not measure social communication per the annotation definition, so it should be excluded.

The contrast indexes implicit event-simulation based on object-picture/word matching (Imp - Control). Although the paper frames event simulation as relevant to social cognition in general, this particular task/contrast involves situational inference from object stimuli rather than explicit social cues, mentalizing, or other social-processing constructs. The analysis is therefore not measuring social processing as defined by the annotation criteria.

The contrast (Explicit vs Implicit event simulation) is a whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrast in healthy adults and the task probes event simulation processes that the authors link to social cognition (mentalizing/trait inference). The explicit ES activation pattern (mPFC, PCC, TPJ/temporal cortex) is canonical for social processing, so this analysis meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast ‘Implicit (Imp - Control)’ indexes event-simulation from object/contextual pictures, not tasks that probe perception or understanding of other people (mental states, animacy or action perception in social scenarios). Therefore it does not meet the requirement of measuring Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast (Explicit > Implicit event simulation) comes from a task probing situational inference/future prediction, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Although likely a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task domain does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The contrast (Explicit > Implicit event simulation) probes situational inference/future-prediction and general social cognition/mentalizing, not social communication per the annotation definition (which targets exchange of socially relevant information such as facial/non‑facial reception/production, cooperation, kinship, etc.). Although healthy-group whole‑brain data, the task does not measure social communication as required.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults (Explicit > Implicit ES), the task probes general event simulation from object pictures rather than explicit perception/understanding of other people (mental states, traits, or social interactions). The stimuli/contrast do not target social cognition (e.g., mentalizing, animacy/action perception of others), so it does not meet the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

The contrast (Explicit > Implicit event simulation) reflects situational inference/event simulation, not tasks or contrasts that probe self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although regions like medial PFC are reported, the task paradigm does not measure Perception and Understanding of the Self, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes event simulation/future-prediction, not affiliation or attachment. Although likely a whole-brain group task in healthy adults, the task manipulations (implicit/explicit inference and future-prediction of object-based situations) do not probe attachment-related processes (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger), so it fails the domain inclusion criterion.

The contrast indexes a future-prediction component of event simulation using contextually related object pictures; the task as described does not explicitly target social processes (e.g., mentalizing, perception/understanding of others) and appears non‑social/situation-focused. Although the authors note links between ES and social cognition, this specific analysis is not clearly a social-processing task and therefore does not meet the annotation inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes event simulation and future prediction from object-based picture-word tasks, not an exchange or processing of socially communicative signals (e.g., facial/expressive cues, social interaction, kinship, cooperation). Although the study likely used healthy adults and whole-brain contrasts, the task does not measure Social Communication as defined by the annotation criteria.

The contrast (Future prediction [Ftr - Exp]) indexes prediction of situational/event outcomes, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or self-related judgment. Although it appears to be a whole-brain, group-level analysis on healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the domain inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain main effect of emotion from an fMRI task using facial expressions (social/emotional stimuli) measuring perception of others' emotions — a social processing construct — and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast. The study context indicates a typical healthy adult VSTM sample.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast isolates the future-prediction component of event simulation (predicting consequences of situations implied by object pictures). It does not target perception or understanding of other people (mental states, traits, actions toward others) or an explicitly social/mentalizing task, so it does not meet the 'perception_others' content criterion.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults (main effect of emotion), the task probes visual short-term memory for emotional (angry) faces — i.e., threat/emotion processing — not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the affiliation_attachment category.

This is a whole-brain main effect of emotion for face VSTM (angry vs other expressions) in a perceptual/emotion task about others' faces, not a task or contrast probing self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

This is a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) main effect of emotion from a task involving encoding/maintenance of facial emotional expressions (angry/happy/neutral) in visual short-term memory. That maps onto Reception of Facial Communication (a Social Communication subconstruct). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast and is consistent with a healthy adult task sample, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate main effect of emotion (voxelwise Talairach coordinates/clusters) from an fMRI study of emotional face memory in (presumably) healthy adults. The contrast reflects perception/processing of others' emotional expressions (understanding others' emotional states), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, univariate whole-brain contrast (main effect of emotion, FDR<.05) from a task involving emotional face stimuli (angry vs neutral), indexing perception/processing of others' emotions in healthy adults (visual short-term memory for faces). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

Although this is a whole-brain group-level contrast in healthy adults (main effect of emotion), the task contrasts memory for angry versus neutral faces (emotion/threat processing), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation/bonding). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criterion.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (Angry vs Neutral; main effect of emotion) from a VSTM task using facial expressions in a healthy adult sample. It indexes perception/reception of facial affect (angry vs neutral), which falls under the Reception of Facial Communication subconstruct of Social Communication. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (main effect of emotion: Angry vs Neutral) in a healthy adult sample, indexing neural responses to others' emotional facial expressions. The contrast indexes visual short-term memory load for emotional (angry) faces, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation).
