It is a within-group task-evoked social-perception contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or a clinical/group comparison), so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrast (human > robot), the task probes human animacy/person-perception and belief manipulations rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, bonding, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the content criteria for an affiliation/attachment task.

The contrast compares observation of human versus robot agents (other-focused animacy/perception), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency related to the participant. Although it is a whole-brain group task contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This analysis appears to be multivariate decoding/predictive mapping of trial-wise attribute values in food and altruistic choices rather than a group-level univariate, voxelwise task contrast probing Perception and Understanding of Others. The focus is on value/attribute representations during choice (not an explicit perception-of-others contrast such as Loved vs Stranger or mental-state attribution), and the reported analysis is not a whole-brain univariate task-evoked map required by the inclusion criteria. Therefore it should be excluded.

This is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast (observing a human > robot performing an action), which probes action/animacy perception — a subcomponent of Perception and Understanding of Others. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (robot > human agent) probes perception of agent animacy/action observation and belief manipulation, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content criteria for the affiliation_attachment category.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (robot > human agent) from an fMRI task probing perception of agents/animacy and knowledge cues about humanness—clearly a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group clinical contrast and appears to be from healthy adult participants, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast (robot > human agent) indexes perception of external agents (observing a robot vs a human) and pertains to social perception of others/animacy, not processes of self-awareness, agency, self-knowledge, or self-related judgments. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self per the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (robot > human agent) indexes person perception/animacy and action observation driven by stimulus and belief cues, not an exchange or processing of communicative signals. The task does not measure social communication (receptive or productive facial/non‑facial communication or communicative interactions), so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (robot > human agent) from healthy adult participants, indexing observation of actions/animacy (action perception/person perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it fits the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain group task in healthy adults (human > robot agent), the paradigm probes person perception/animacy and action observation/mentalizing rather than exchange or reception/production of socially communicative signals. It does not measure social communication (facial or non‑facial communicative behaviors or interactions), so it does not meet the "social_communication" inclusion criteria.

This contrast tests effects of perceived agent animacy (human motion capture vs computer-generated animation) during action observation, not measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain group task in healthy adults, the task and contrast do not assess affiliation or attachment processes.

This is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (belief: human motion-capture > computer-generated animation) from a healthy adult fMRI study probing perceptions of others/animacy and engaging person-perception/mentalizing networks. It is a task-evoked social-processing contrast (perception/understanding of others), not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast reflects perception of others' animacy (belief that actions were generated by human motion-capture vs computer animation) and engages person-perception/mentalizing networks, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain healthy-group contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of the Self and therefore does not meet the construct criteria.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, within-group effect in healthy adults, it indexes belief about agent animacy during action observation (human motion-capture vs computer-generated) rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or a communication task. The contrast probes person-perception/animacy and mentalizing processes, not social-communication (receptive or productive communication) as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (human motion-capture belief > computer-generated animation belief) from a healthy adult fMRI sample. The contrast targets knowledge-based animacy/perception of others (belief about an agent's human vs computer origin), which fits the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct (Animacy Perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or patient vs control comparison.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (computer-generated animation > human motion-capture belief) from an fMRI task that manipulates beliefs about agent animacy while participants observed actions. The task probes perception/understanding of others (social processing), the sample is healthy adults, and the analysis is not ROI/ connectivity or a between-group comparison — so it meets inclusion criteria.

The contrast reflects processing of others' animacy/agent origin (computer-generated vs motion-captured human) rather than any self-related awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or self-comparison. Although it is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults, the task manipulates perceived agent animacy/belief (computer-generated animation vs human motion capture) and probes social perception of animacy rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, love, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' annotation.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group‑level contrast in a healthy adult sample, the contrast reflects animacy/agent perception and belief manipulation (computer‑generated vs motion‑capture) rather than a social communication task (exchange of socially relevant information, receptive/expressive communication). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the contrast measures Social Communication.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (main effect of belief: computer-generated animation > human motion capture) from a healthy adult sample, targeting knowledge cues to animacy/action perception and social perception. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group clinical contrast, and thus meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise within-subject contrast in a healthy adult sample examining perception/interpretation of agents (human vs robot) and belief manipulations — a social perception/mentalizing task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast tests perceptual/belief cues to animacy (congruent vs incongruent human/robot form–belief pairings) from an action-observation paradigm. It does not measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the task/content criteria for 'affiliation_attachment'.

The contrast tests perception of others (congruent vs incongruent agent/belief pairings about human vs robot animacy), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or judgments about the participant themself. Although it is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

Although this is a healthy-group, whole-brain within-subject contrast, the contrast indexes animacy/agent belief and person-perception / mentalizing processes (congruent vs incongruent agent/belief pairings). It does not measure social communication (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals or exchange of socially relevant information) as required by the annotation, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (interaction: congruent > incongruent agent/belief pairings) from an fMRI task in healthy adults probing perception of others (animacy/action perception when observing human vs robot actions and belief manipulations). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group (clinical) analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast from an fMRI study in healthy adults probing perception of human vs. robot agents and belief cues to animacy — a clear social perception/understanding task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes incongruency between agent form and belief about animacy (human vs robot; motion-capture vs computer-generated), i.e. perceptual/belief manipulation of animacy, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain task contrast in (presumably) healthy adults, the psychological construct does not match the affiliation/attachment domain.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes perception of agent animacy and belief congruency (human vs robot form and motion-belief pairing) rather than an exchange of social information or communicative behavior. It reflects person perception/mentalizing processes, not a social communication task/contrast, so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes perception of others' animacy and belief/agent congruency (observation of incongruent vs congruent agent/belief pairings). It probes social perception/mentalizing about external agents (human vs robot and beliefs about motion origin), not processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, agency, or self-related judgments required for the "perception_self" annotation.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast in healthy adults probing agent animacy/person perception (interaction of agent form and belief about origin), which falls squarely under Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/action/person perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-subject clinical-group contrast.

The analysis examines prosodic speech (linguistic/emotional prosody) in high-functioning autism and controls, not tasks or contrasts targeting affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). In addition the study involves a clinical group (HFA) versus controls rather than a single healthy adult sample generalizable to the healthy population. Therefore it does not meet the task domain or sample inclusion criteria.

The analysis comes from a study of high-functioning autism and reports brain activation in HFA and controls. This involves a clinical group and/or between-group contrasts rather than a group-level whole-brain map from a healthy adult sample alone, so it fails the sample and between-group inclusion criteria for the "social_processing_all" annotation.

This analysis concerns prosodic speech processing in high-functioning autism and controls (linguistic/emotional prosody), not tasks probing Perception and Understanding of the Self (e.g., self-awareness, agency, social comparison). Although controls are present, the contrast examines prosody/language processing rather than self-related judgments, so it does not meet the task/domain inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis comes from a study comparing high-functioning autism (HFA) and controls (table caption: 'Brain activation in HFA and in controls'), so it is not an analysis on a healthy adult sample alone. Per the inclusion rules, analyses must be whole-brain group maps from healthy participants only; studies involving clinical groups or clinical vs. control comparisons are excluded.

The table/analysis comes from a clinical study including high‑functioning autism (HFA) and controls and the caption reports activations in HFA and in controls. There is no clear indication this entry is a group‑level, whole‑brain map derived solely from a healthy adult sample (nor that it is not a between‑group contrast). Because the sample/contrast is not clearly an independent healthy adult whole‑brain task activation (and may reflect patient data or patient vs control comparisons), it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast comes from a prosodic speech study (linguistic/emotional prosody in autism vs controls), not a task assessing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although the group 'Controls' are healthy participants, the task and contrast do not measure affiliation/attachment, so it fails the task-specific inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports within-group, whole-brain activation for the control group during a prosodic speech task that includes emotional prosody (a social-communication / emotion-recognition process). It is not a between-group contrast or ROI/connectivity analysis, and thus meets the social_processing_all criteria. (Note: age of participants is not explicitly stated in the excerpt; inclusion assumes the control sample are healthy adults as implied by the study context.)

The reported analysis concerns prosodic speech processing in high-functioning autism and controls (linguistic/emotional prosody). This probes speech/emotion perception, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, agency, or social-comparison required for the 'perception_self' construct. Therefore it does not meet the construct-specific inclusion criteria.

The analysis labeled "Controls" reports within-group brain activation for the healthy/control group from a task probing linguistic and emotional prosody. The contrast appears to be a group-level task-evoked activation in controls (not a between-group contrast, ROI, or connectivity analysis), so it meets the inclusion criteria. Note: this decision assumes the reported activations are whole-brain/univariate results as typically presented in such tables.

The entry labeled 'Controls' refers to the healthy control group (not a patient vs control contrast) and reports task-evoked brain activation for prosodic speech. Emotional prosody involves perceiving others' emotional states, which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others. The result is from a task fMRI group activation (whole-brain univariate) in healthy adults, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The analysis reports activations common to HFA (clinical) and control groups rather than being derived from a healthy adult sample alone. Inclusion criteria require group-level whole-brain results from healthy participants only; analyses that include clinical groups (even conjunctions) do not meet the sample requirement.

The analysis comes from a study of prosodic speech in high-functioning autism (HFA) and controls, not a task targeting affiliation/attachment. This analysis reports activations in HFA and controls (a clinical vs control context) for prosodic speech processing. This is a between-group contrast (HFA > Controls) involving a clinical group (high-functioning autism) rather than a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone. Therefore it fails the sample and analysis-type inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis is a conjunction/common-activation across HFA (a clinical group) and controls, not a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone. The analysis reports activations in both high-functioning autism (HFA) and controls (a conjunction/common activation across patient and control groups). Inclusion requires a whole-brain group map from healthy adults alone (generalizable to the healthy population). Because this analysis involves a clinical group (HFA) rather than being a healthy-only group-level map, it does not meet the sample criteria and should be excluded.

This analysis is a between-group contrast (HFA > Controls) involving a clinical group (high‑functioning autism) rather than a within‑group, whole‑brain map from healthy adults measuring Perception/Self. It therefore fails the sample and contrast inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (HFA > Controls) comparing a clinical group (high-functioning autism) to controls. Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults only (not a patient vs control comparison). Therefore it fails the sample/contrast inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (HFA > Controls) comparing a clinical group (high‑functioning autism) to controls. This is a within-group (controls) whole-brain task contrast reporting deactivations during a prosodic speech task (emotional/linguistic prosody = social communication/perception). This is a within-group, voxelwise contrast from the healthy control group (deactivation in controls) collected during a prosodic speech task. The contrast is not a between‑group comparison, ROI, or connectivity analysis, so it satisfies the inclusion criteria. (Caveat: inclusion assumes the reported controls are healthy adults and the map is whole‑brain; if either is not true, it should be excluded.)

Although this is a within-group (controls) whole-brain contrast, the task probes prosodic and emotional speech processing, not Perception and Understanding of the Self. Therefore it does not meet the required task/domain criterion for the 'perception_self' annotation.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > HFA: brain deactivation). The inclusion rules require a group-level, within-group whole-brain map from healthy adults only; between-group contrasts are explicitly excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > HFA) from a study comparing healthy controls to a clinical group (high-functioning autism), not a within-group healthy adult whole-brain map. Although the sample appears to be healthy adults and the contrast is likely a group-level whole-brain task contrast, the task (judging biological motion as facing toward vs away) and the FA>FT contrast measure stimulus direction/social involvement potential, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although this is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast on healthy adults, the task contrasts (human-like walkers vs point-light displays; judging facing direction) probe biological-motion/social-perception processes rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). The STIMULUS*DIRECTION contrast tests perception of social orientation/intent from biological motion (PLDs and human-like walkers), which constitutes reception of non-facial social communication. This is a group-level task fMRI contrast (STIMULUS × DIRECTION) from a study of healthy adults performing judgments about biological motion (PLDs and human-like walkers facing toward/away). It probes action/animacy perception (Perception and Understanding of Others) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast appears to be a group-level whole-brain task fMRI comparison in healthy adults, the task probes biological motion and perceived social directionality (PLD vs human-like walkers) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). This is a within-group, univariate fMRI contrast (FT_PLD > HL) from a task where healthy adult participants judged facing direction of point-light displays vs human-like walkers — a social perception/mentalizing task. This is a group-level, within-subject univariate whole-brain contrast comparing PLD vs HL stimuli (FT_PLD > HL) in a task where participants judged whether point-light displays and human-like walkers were facing toward/away — a perceptual judgement of socially relevant body cues (reception of non-facial communication). The contrast (FT_HL > PLD) compares stimulus types/direction of biological motion (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) in a task judging facing direction. This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (HL > PLD) from healthy adult participants probing perception of biological/social motion (animacy/action perception). The contrast compares stimulus types/direction in a biological-motion task (PLD vs HL facing direction) aimed at social perception and mentalizing, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, cooperation). The contrast examines biological-motion/social-intention processing (HL vs PLD; facing toward/away) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). The contrast FA_HL > PLD reflects perceptual processing of others' biological motion / stimulus type (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) and stimulus direction (facing toward/away) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (PLD facing toward > facing away) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of others (action/animacy and social orientation). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (PLD facing toward > facing away) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological motion/social intent. This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (HL_FA > FT) from a study in healthy adult participants performing a social perception task (judging direction/ social involvement of human-like walkers/point-light displays). This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis map (aggregate of ~1,000 studies using the keyword “social”), not a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast from a healthy adult sample measuring affiliation/attachment. This analysis reports an automated NeuroSynth meta-analytic map (coordinate-based meta-analysis of ~1,000 studies), not a single-study, group-level voxelwise task-evoked statistical map from a healthy adult sample. NeuroSynth maps aggregate heterogeneous studies/populations and are not equivalent to a univariate whole-brain group contrast from a healthy control sample, so it fails the "whole-brain evidence" and sample criteria.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis map (aggregating ~1,000 studies), not a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrast from a healthy adult sample measuring a specific social-communication task/contrast. It therefore fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ and task-specific inclusion criteria (and is heterogeneous across study types), so it should be excluded.

This analysis is a NeuroSynth automated meta-analysis map (keyword = “social”), not a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain statistical map from a healthy adult sample probing Perception/Understanding of Self. This entry is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analytic map aggregated across ~1,000 "social" studies rather than a single group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast in a healthy adult sample measuring a Perception/Understanding-of-Others task. This is a NeuroSynth automated meta-analysis of studies using the keyword “social” and a generic social vs. non-social contrast. The contrast is broad social processing rather than a specific affiliation/attachment task, and the meta-analytic map aggregates heterogeneous studies (potentially including non-healthy samples), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This analysis is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis of 'social' studies (and a confirmatory social vs. non-social image contrast), not a task or contrast specifically probing Perception and Understanding of the Self (agency or self-knowledge). This is a NeuroSynth automated meta-analysis (literature-level association map), not a single group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from a healthy adult sample. Excluded: the reported analysis is an ROI analysis (from a subset of adults) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task map, and the study examines face-specialization/development rather than an affiliation/attachment task/contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger).

This entry is a NeuroSynth automated meta-analytic map (aggregate of ~1,000 'social' studies), not a single group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast from a healthy adult sample measuring Perception and Understanding of Others. This entry reports region-of-interest (ROI) analyses (from a subset of adults) rather than a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrast. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task probes empathic/emotional processing (emotional vs neutral video clips) rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (neutral > emotional) in a sample of healthy adults (n=34) using an empathic accuracy task consisting of autobiographical video clips — a social-communicative stimulus tapping reception of non-facial/facial affect and verbal social information. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Therefore it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic-accuracy task (rating narrators' emotional intensity), which directly probes perception/understanding of others' emotional states. The contrast (neutral > emotional video clips) is task-evoked and not an ROI/connectivity or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis probes empathic accuracy (tracking others' emotional intensity; emotional > neutral clips and correlations with Z-EA scores), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, parental/peer bonding, loved-one vs stranger). Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group contrast, the task assesses empathy rather than affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the annotation criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in a healthy adult sample (n=34) linking brain activity during an empathic accuracy (video-based) task to individual Z-scored empathic-accuracy scores. The task and contrast index perception/understanding of others (social processing), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults linking brain activity to empathic accuracy (Z-EA) measured during an empathic-accuracy task using dynamic social video clips. The contrast reflects brain activity related to empathic accuracy (Z‑EA) — i.e., tracking others' emotions — not processes of self‑perception or self‑knowledge. This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults linking brain activation during an empathic-accuracy task (tracking others' emotional intensity) to individual Z-EA scores. This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adults relating brain activity during an empathic-accuracy (social) task to Z-scored empathic-accuracy (Z-EA) scores (negative correlation). It is task-evoked, not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast, and measures social processing (perception/understanding of others), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis in healthy adults, the task probes empathic accuracy (tracking others' emotional intensity) rather than affiliation/attachment per se. The contrast relates brain activity to empathic accuracy (Z-EA scores) and not to affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., loved‑one vs stranger, kinship, bonding, cooperation), so it does not meet the task/content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

The analysis examines brain activity in 34 healthy adult participants and reports a group-level, voxelwise relationship (negatively related to Z‑EA empathic accuracy scores) during an empathic accuracy task. This analysis indexes neural activity related to empathic accuracy for others (tracking narrators' emotions) rather than processes of self-perception/self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain, group-level map in healthy adults, the task and contrast reflect perception/understanding of others, not the Perception and Understanding of Self construct.

This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analysis in a sample of healthy adults linking task-evoked activation during an empathic accuracy task (tracking others' emotional states) to individual EA scores. This is a group-level, task-evoked univariate whole-brain analysis in a sample of healthy adults (N=34) relating continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity — a social/empathy-related measure (perception and understanding of others) — to brain activity. Although this is a whole‑brain, group‑level analysis in healthy adults (positive correlation with participants' emotional‑intensity ratings), the task probes empathic accuracy/emotional tracking of narrators rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast index affiliation and attachment.

Healthy adult sample (N=34); the reported analysis is a group-level, voxelwise correlation between participants' continuous ratings of narrators' emotional intensity and brain activity (whole-brain univariate task-evoked map). This analysis indexes participants' tracking of others' emotional intensity (empathic accuracy) — i.e., perception/understanding of another person’s emotions — not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. Although it appears to be a healthy-group, whole-brain univariate contrast, it does not meet the "Perception and Understanding of Self" construct, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adults linking participants' continuous ratings of another person's emotional intensity to brain activity—i.e., perception/understanding of others' emotional states. This analysis comes from an empathic-accuracy task (tracking others' emotional intensity) assessing empathy-related processes, not affiliation or attachment per se. This is a group-level, within-subject voxelwise analysis in a healthy adult sample (N=34) linking continuous ratings of another person's emotional intensity to BOLD activity during an empathic accuracy task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adult participants that links brain activity to continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity while watching autobiographical video clips. The task indexes reception of socially relevant, non-facial communicative signals (verbal/prosodic and expressive content), so it fits the Social Communication construct and meets the sample and analysis-type inclusion criteria (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group).

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in a sample of healthy adults (n=34) using participants' continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity while watching autobiographical videos — a direct measure of perceiving/understanding others' emotional states (empathic accuracy). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This analysis indexes neural activity related to participants' ratings of another person's (narrator's) emotional intensity — i.e., tracking others' emotions/empathic accuracy — not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about one's own internal states. Healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind (social) task; the DEC>COOP is a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast (ToM: deception vs cooperation) reported in the table (height/extent thresholds), not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — it therefore meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (DEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants performing a task contrasting deception vs cooperation, which directly probes social communication (cooperation/deception). This is a within-group (controls) task-evoked whole-brain contrast (deactivation) from a healthy adult control sample in a study that explicitly probes prosody, including emotional prosody. This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain task contrast (DEC>COOPDEC) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind/social task (deception vs cooperation/deception). This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (DEC>COOP) from healthy adult volunteers performing a theory-of-mind task comparing deception versus cooperation — a direct measure of perception/understanding of others' intentions. Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the DEC>COOP contrast probes theory-of-mind reasoning about other characters' intentions (deception vs cooperation). This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (DEC>COOPDEC) from healthy volunteers in a social interaction (cooperation/deception) ToM task. It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis and directly measures social communication, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast (deception > cooperation/deception) from healthy adult participants in a Theory-of-Mind task assessing others' intentions/expectations (Understanding Mental States). Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the DEC>COOPDEC contrast reflects theory-of-mind reasoning about other characters' intentions (deception vs cooperative/deceptive interactions). This contrast indexes understanding of others, not self-related processing, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked voxelwise contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind/social interaction task. Although the study used healthy adult participants and reports whole-brain task contrasts, the specific contrast DEC>COOPDEC indexes deception-related processing rather than affiliation/attachment. This is a group-level, within-subject voxelwise contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind task about cooperation/deception—clearly measuring social processing (understanding others' intentions). Although the contrast is a whole‑brain, group-level map from healthy adults, it indexes theory-of-mind reasoning about other characters' intentions (cooperation vs deception). This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) from a ToM task in healthy adult participants probing reasoning about others' intentions/expectations (cooperation/deception), so it matches the Perception and Understanding of Others construct and meets inclusion (not ROI, not connectivity, not between-group).

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (COOPDEC > COOP) from healthy adult subjects in a theory-of-mind paradigm probing others' intentions/expectations (Perception and Understanding of Others). This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants assessing cooperation/deception in a theory-of-mind task. Although the contrast is a whole-brain, healthy-group task contrast, it indexes theory-of-mind reasoning about protagonists' intentions (cooperation vs deception) — i.e., mentalizing about others — rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. This is a within-group whole-brain task contrast (COOP>DEC) from healthy volunteers performing a theory-of-mind/social task. It indexes social processing (cooperation vs deception) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (COOP>DEC) from healthy adult participants assessing cooperation vs deception in a social interaction/ToM task. Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (COOP>DEC), the task probes theory-of-mind reasoning about other characters' intentions (cooperation vs deception) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (COOP>COOPDEC) in healthy adult participants from a theory-of-mind task about cooperation/deception. This is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (Table name: Region of interest analysis) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map, and ROI analyses are explicitly excluded. Excluded: the analysis is an ROI-based analysis (table label 'Regions of interest'), not a whole-brain voxelwise group map, and the task (viewing dynamic pupils/salience) does not target affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger or kinship/cooperation paradigms). Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast in healthy controls (direct > averted gaze), the task probes gaze perception/theory-of-mind rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, close-relationship bonding).
