This is a seed-based psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analysis, which falls under the exclusion criteria (seed-based/effective connectivity). Although the sample and task are social, the analysis is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked map measuring affiliation/attachment.

This analysis is a seed-based functional connectivity (PPI) covariate analysis (right IPL seed), which falls under the exclusion criteria for seed-based/effective connectivity analyses. Although the sample is healthy adults and the task is social in nature, the result is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise map, so it should be excluded.

This is a seed-based connectivity analysis (PPI) relating IPL connectivity to behavior, not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map. Per the exclusion criteria, seed-based/effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI) are excluded.

This is a seed-based PPI connectivity analysis (controlled PPI − free PPI seeded in right IPL). The inclusion criteria require a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) contrast measuring Perception/Self; the exclusion criteria explicitly rule out seed-based/PPI or other connectivity analyses. Therefore it should be excluded.

This analysis is a between-group (age group) effect comparing adolescents and young adults. Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain task map from healthy adult participants alone and excludes between-group contrasts/interactions and mixed-age (adolescent vs adult) comparisons. Although the task is social, the age-group contrast violates the exclusion criteria.

This analysis reflects a between-group (age group) effect comparing adolescents and young adults rather than a within-group, healthy adult whole-brain task contrast. The sample includes adolescents (not adults only), and the contrast is a group comparison/interaction outcome (and the paper also reports ROI follow-ups). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria for a whole‑brain, healthy adult Perception/Self contrast.

Excluded: the analysis involves a between-group age comparison (adolescents vs young adults) rather than a single healthy adult sample, and the reported effects were from ROI analyses in bilateral ventral striatum rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate map. This violates the sample, whole-brain, and between-group exclusion criteria.

Excluded because this analysis is a between-group (age group) comparison involving adolescents and young adults rather than a whole-brain map from a healthy adult sample alone. The inclusion criteria require group-level univariate whole-brain maps generalizable to the healthy adult population and disallow between-group contrasts/interactions. Although the task probes social self-evaluation, the age-group contrast violates the sample/contrast inclusion rules.

The analysis derives from a developmental sample (early adolescents and young adults) and is part of an Age group × evaluative perspective × domain ANOVA, i.e., it involves between-group (age) comparisons. Inclusion requires group-level whole-brain task maps from healthy adult participants alone (no developmental between-group contrasts). Therefore this analysis does not meet the adult-only / no between-group-contrast criteria.

This analysis is a between-group (age group) effect comparing adolescents and young adults rather than a within-group whole-brain task contrast from a healthy adult sample. The sample includes adolescents (not only healthy adults) and the contrast is an age-group main effect (between-group), both of which violate the inclusion criteria (requires healthy adult-only, group-level whole-brain task contrasts and excludes between-group contrasts). Therefore it should not be included under perception_others.

Excluded. The analysis comes from a developmental study including early adolescents and young adults (not an adult-only healthy sample) and is part of an Age group × evaluative perspective × domain ANOVA (i.e. involves between-age-group factors/interaction). In addition, the reported effects were emphasized in ROI analyses of ventral striatum rather than a group-level whole-brain map targeted to affiliation/attachment. The task (self- and reflected self-evaluations) is social but does not clearly match the required affiliation/attachment task/contrast criteria.

Although the contrast probes self-evaluative processing (direct and reflected self-evaluations), the reported analysis arises from a sample that includes both adolescents and young adults and is part of an Age group × Evaluative perspective × Domain ANOVA. The inclusion criteria require group-level whole‑brain maps from healthy adult participants only (not mixed-age or age‑group comparisons). Because this analysis is not restricted to an adult‑only healthy sample (and is embedded in between‑group ANOVA effects), it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This analysis is not eligible. The study includes both adolescents and adults and the reported effects involve age-group × perspective interactions (not a whole‑brain, healthy‑adult only group map). Moreover the focal results discussed derive from ROI follow‑ups (ventral striatum) and the reported contrast is a general evaluative‑perspective effect rather than a clean whole‑brain ‘perception/understanding of others’ (other vs. stranger/loved one) contrast. These features violate the sample and analysis-type inclusion criteria.

This analysis reflects a developmental (age-group) × perspective × domain interaction comparing adolescents and adults (a between-group interaction) rather than a whole-brain, group-level univariate map from a healthy adult sample alone. It also reports ROI follow-ups in adolescents. Because it involves between-group contrasts/interaction and is not an adult-only whole-brain task map, it fails the inclusion criteria.

Excluded: the reported analysis involves an age-group × evaluative-perspective × domain interaction (a between-group effect including adolescents and adults) and the key results were from ROI analyses in ventral striatum rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate map limited to healthy adults. Thus it does not meet the adult-only, whole-brain, within-group inclusion criteria.

Excluded. The reported analysis involves an age-group × evaluative-perspective × domain interaction (a between-group effect across adolescents and adults) and the key findings are from ROI analyses (ventral striatum) rather than a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise map in healthy adults. Although the task involves a close-peer (best friend) perspective (relevant to affiliation), it fails the sample (adult-only) and whole-brain / between-group criteria.

This analysis tests an Age group × evaluative perspective interaction (adolescents vs. adults) — i.e., a between-group comparison — and the reported follow-up uses ROI analyses in ventral striatum. Inclusion requires a whole‑brain, group‑level univariate map generalizable to healthy adults (no between‑group contrasts or ROI‑only results). Therefore it does not meet the criteria.

Excluded: the reported analysis involves an age-group × perspective interaction (adolescents vs young adults), i.e. a between-group/developmental contrast rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate map generalizable to a healthy adult sample. The paper also reports ROI analyses in ventral striatum. These features violate the inclusion criteria (healthy-adult whole-brain task map; no between-group/interactions or ROI-only results).

The analysis comes from a developmental sample (early adolescents and young adults) and is part of an Age group × evaluative perspective × domain ANOVA. The inclusion criteria require analyses on healthy adult participants alone (generalizable to the healthy adult population). Because this analysis includes adolescents and involves an age-group factor (not an adult-only whole-brain map), it does not meet the sample requirement and should be excluded.

This analysis involves a developmental (age group × evaluative perspective × domain) interaction comparing adolescents and young adults (between-group contrast), and thus is not a univariate whole‑brain map generalizable to a healthy adult sample alone. The inclusion criteria require analyses on healthy adult participants and exclude between‑group contrasts/interactions. Therefore it should be excluded.

The reported analysis comes from a mixed sample (early adolescents and young adults) and reflects an age-group × perspective × domain ANOVA rather than a whole-brain group-level map confined to healthy adults. The inclusion criteria require analyses from healthy adult participants only (generalizable to the adult population), so this analysis should be excluded.

The analysis comes from an ANOVA that includes both early adolescents and young adults (mixed-age sample), not a healthy-adult-only group as required. Although the task involves peer/close‑friend social evaluation (relevant to affiliation), the sample criterion (adult participants only) is not met, so it must be excluded.

The reported analysis comes from an ANOVA that includes both adolescents and young adults (Age group × evaluative perspective × domain). The inclusion criteria require a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adult participants (generalizable to the healthy adult population) or contrasts within the adult/control group only. Because this analysis pools/compares age groups (not an adult-only map) it does not meet the sample requirement and should be excluded.

The reported analysis is a main effect of domain from an Age group × evaluative perspective × domain ANOVA in a mixed sample of early adolescents and young adults, not an analysis limited to healthy adult participants. It also does not appear to isolate Perception/Understanding of Others (e.g., an other-vs-self contrast) but rather compares stimulus domains (academic/physical/social). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria for the perception_others annotation.

The reported analysis is an Age group × domain interaction comparing adolescents and young adults (a between-group interaction) and the paper highlights region-of-interest results in bilateral ventral striatum. The inclusion criteria require whole‑brain, group-level univariate maps from a healthy adult sample (not between-group contrasts or ROI analyses). Although the task involves social/peer evaluation (affiliation-relevant), the analysis fails the sample/contrast and ROI requirements, so it should be excluded.

Excluded. The reported analysis involves a developmental (age group) interaction and was assessed with region-of-interest analyses rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map from a healthy adult sample. Inclusion requires a whole-brain, group-level univariate map generalizable to healthy adults and no between-group contrasts/ROI-only results.

Excluded: the analysis is not a whole‑brain group-level map from a healthy adult sample only. It involves age-group comparisons (adolescents vs adults) and reports ROI results in bilateral ventral striatum (and age-group interactions), both of which violate the inclusion criteria (no between‑group/subgroup contrasts and no ROI‑only analyses).

This analysis involves an Age group × domain interaction comparing early adolescents and young adults (a between-group contrast including non-adult participants). The inclusion criteria require analyses on healthy adult participants only and exclude between-group contrasts/interactions, so this analysis should be excluded.

The analysis is a mixed-age (adolescents vs. adults) Age group × domain interaction (a between-group effect) rather than a group-level whole-brain contrast from a healthy adult sample. The contrast involves between-group comparisons/interaction and follow-up ROI analyses, both of which fall under the exclusion criteria.

This analysis reports an age group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction from a developmental sample (early adolescents vs young adults) and includes ROI follow-ups. Inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level univariate maps from healthy adult participants (not between-group interactions or subgroup comparisons) and exclude ROI analyses. Because this is a between-group developmental interaction (and involves ROI results), it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Excluded. The reported analysis involves an age group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction (comparison of adolescents vs young adults), so it is a between-group interaction rather than a within-healthy-adult whole-brain map. Additionally the key follow-up findings are reported from ROI analyses in the adolescent sample. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level maps generalizable to healthy adults (adult-only) and exclude ROI and between-group contrasts, so this analysis does not meet the criteria.

Does not meet inclusion criteria. The reported result is an age-group × evaluative-perspective × domain interaction and subsequent ROI analyses in bilateral ventral striatum (and effects driven by adolescents), rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise map from a healthy adult sample. It therefore involves between-group interaction/age comparison and ROI-based (not whole-brain) results, both of which are exclusionary.

Exclude. The analysis involves age-group comparisons (adolescents and adults) and reports a group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction, which is a between-group effect (excluded). The reported findings rely on ROI analyses in ventral striatum rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise map generalizable to healthy adults. Finally, the task probes self-/reflected-evaluation (self-processing/social evaluation) rather than the defined Social Communication constructs (receptive/production facial or non-facial communication), so it does not meet the task/contrast inclusion criteria.

This analysis involves a mixed sample (early adolescents and young adults) and reports an Age group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction (a between-group effect). The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level contrasts generalizable to healthy adults only and exclude between-group contrasts/interactions and ROI-only results. Therefore this analysis does not meet the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

Excluded because the reported analysis involves a between-group interaction (age group: adolescents vs young adults) rather than a group-level map from a single healthy adult sample. The sample includes minors (adolescents) and the effect is a subgroup (age) interaction/contrast, which violates the inclusion criteria (no between-group contrasts/interactions and must be on healthy adults only).

Exclude. The analysis involves an age-group × perspective × domain interaction (between-group effect across adolescents and adults) and the reported results relied on region-of-interest analyses. Inclusion requires whole-brain, group-level univariate maps generalizable to a healthy adult sample only. This study includes adolescents and uses between-group interactions and ROI analyses, violating the sample and analysis-type inclusion/exclusion criteria.

Excluded: the reported result is a mixed-age (adolescent vs adult) Age group × perspective × domain interaction (a between-group effect) and the follow-up was ROI-based in bilateral ventral striatum. Inclusion requires whole-brain, group-level voxelwise maps from healthy adult participants only (no between-group interactions and no ROI analyses).

Excluded: the reported analysis tests an Age group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction (adolescents vs young adults), i.e. a between-group contrast/subgroup interaction, which is disallowed. In addition the sample includes adolescents (not healthy adults only). The paper also reports ROI analyses (ventral striatum) for key effects, further violating whole-brain, healthy-adult requirements.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in a healthy adult sample correlating AQ with activation to variable vs. constant eye gaze—a social perception task (social attention/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis tests a three-way interaction including age group (adolescents vs young adults) rather than a single healthy adult group, and the reported effects were from region-of-interest analyses in ventral striatum. The inclusion criteria require whole‑brain, group‑level maps from healthy adult samples (not between‑group interactions or ROI results), so this analysis does not qualify.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis in healthy adults, the task contrasts index social attention to eye-gaze (variable vs. constant gaze) and AQ-related variability in gaze processing — not affiliation/attachment or close-relationship processes. The contrast does not probe attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs. stranger comparisons required for the 'affiliation_attachment' category.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise (within healthy typical adults) correlation between AQ and the task contrast variable vs. constant eye gaze. The task probes eye-gaze processing, a core aspect of social communication (facial/eye-contact reception/production), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the sample (typical adults) and the reported analysis appear to be whole-brain, the contrast indexes neural responses to others' eye-gaze and their correlation with AQ (an individual trait). This task measures perception of others' gaze, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the "Perception and Understanding of Self" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analysis in a healthy (typical) adult sample assessing neural responses to others' eye gaze (social perception). The statistic is a subject-level AQ covariate (regression) on the contrast variable vs. constant gaze, not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise. The task involves perception of infant emotional vocalizations, which falls squarely within social processing (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/attachment). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise. Infant cries constitute non-facial social vocal communication (reception of non-facial communication), and the contrast appears to be a whole-brain, univariate between-condition contrast rather than an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in a healthy adult sample (low-distress infant cry > pink noise), the task probes perception of infant/other-related auditory stimuli rather than self-referential processes (self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge). Therefore it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion domain.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise. Infant cries are social cues tied to caregiving/attachment processes, so the Low‑distress cry > pink noise contrast fits the affiliation/attachment domain.

Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women); group-level task-evoked univariate contrast (low-distress infant cry > pink noise) reported as whole-brain activations; contrast probes perception of another's emotional state (infant vocalizations), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing pink noise to low-distress infant cries. The task involves perception of infant cries (a social/affiliative cue), so the contrast probes social processing (even though the direction is non-social > social). It meets the sample and analysis-type inclusion criteria and does not fall under any exclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group contrast on healthy adults, the contrast (Pink Noise > Low‑Distress Cry) does not index an affiliation/attachment task as defined. It contrasts auditory control noise with infant cries (sensory/emotional processing), rather than measuring affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation, bonding). Therefore it does not meet the annotation's task/content requirement.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise. Infant cries are non-facial social communicative auditory signals (reception of non-facial communication), so the contrast meets the social_communication inclusion criteria and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI, not connectivity, not a between-group contrast).

This contrast (pink noise > low-distress infant cry) reflects perception of external auditory/social stimuli, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or social self-comparison. Although the sample is healthy adults and the analysis appears to be a whole-brain group contrast, the task/contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant high-distress cries to pink noise. Perception of infant cries is a social/emotional cue relevant to social processing (perception/understanding of others/affiliation), and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women), group-level whole-brain task contrast (high-distress infant cry > pink noise), and the task probes social/affiliative caregiving responses to infant cues (attachment-related processing), so it meets the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This contrast (High-distress infant cry > pink noise) probes perception of external infant auditory stimuli, not self-related processing. Although the sample is healthy adults and the contrast appears to be a within-group whole-brain task contrast, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of the Self (self-knowledge or agency), so it does not meet the "perception_self" inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast is Pink Noise > Low-Distress Cry (non-social > social). The map therefore reflects regions more active for non-social acoustic noise rather than neural responses indexing perception/understanding of others (infant cries). The contrast does not measure processing of others’ emotional states, so it does not meet the 'perception_others' inclusion requirement.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (high-distress infant cry > pink noise) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women). The contrast probes reception of socially relevant non-facial communication (infant vocalizations), meets inclusion criteria, and is not an ROI/ connectivity or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) contrasting infant high-distress cries versus pink noise. The contrast indexes perception of another's emotional state (infant distress), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, within-subject contrast in healthy adult participants derived from an event-related task presenting infant cries (social auditory signals). The contrast compares social (high-distress cry) vs non-social (pink noise) auditory stimuli and thus probes reception of non-facial social communication. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (pink noise > high-distress infant cry) indexes auditory/perceptual processing of infant stimuli, not processes of self‑knowledge or agency. Although the sample and whole‑brain analysis criteria are met, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

The analysis is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) using infant cries — a social/caregiving stimulus relevant to affiliation/attachment. Although the contrast is pink noise > high-distress cry (control > social), it arises from a task that probes attachment-related processing and meets the inclusion (and does not meet any exclusion) criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group task contrast in healthy adults (nulliparous women) using infant cry stimuli (a social task), the specific contrast is Pink Noise > High-Distress Cry. That contrast indexes greater activation to a non-social control stimulus (pink noise) relative to the social stimulus, and therefore does not measure neural activity reflecting social processing of infant cries. It should be excluded from the 'social_processing_all' annotation.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (low-distress > high-distress infant cries) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women). The contrast probes perception/interpretation of social/emotional infant cues (social processing/affiliation/attachment), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants comparing infant cry types (Low > High distress). Infant cries are social, non‑facial communicative signals (reception of non‑facial communication), so the contrast meets the social_communication inclusion criteria and does not fall under the exclusions (not ROI, not connectivity, not between‑group).

This contrast compares neural responses to low- versus high-distress infant cries (perception of external infant stimuli), not processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or agency. Although it is a whole‑brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self and therefore fails the construct inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI comparison in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) and involves infant cries — auditory cues that convey another's emotional state. Although the reported contrast is pink noise > high-distress cry (control > social), it still stems from a paradigm probing perception of others' emotional signals and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults (nulliparous women) and is not an ROI or connectivity analysis. The task uses infant cries—social cues that elicit caregiving/attachment-related processes—so the contrast (low- vs high-distress cries) is relevant to affiliation/attachment and meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain contrast (Low-distress cry > High-distress cry) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) that probes perception of others' emotional states (infant distress). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women); contrast is a group-level task-evoked univariate whole-brain activation (Happy > Neutral infant faces) assessing perception of emotional/social cues; not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — meets inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The contrast (Happy Face > Neutral Face) is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast in a sample of healthy adult participants (nulliparous women), reporting whole-brain activations (ventral striatum, caudate, vmPFC, OFC). It assesses reception of facial communication (emotional face perception), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast (Happy Face > Neutral Face for infant faces) probes perception of others (infant emotional faces), not processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge or agency. Although it appears to be a whole‑brain, group‑level univariate contrast on healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (Happy face > Neutral face) in healthy adult participants viewing infant emotional expressions. The contrast indexes perception of others' emotional states (infant affect), fits the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct, and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrast (Happy > Neutral infant faces) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women). The task probes perception of infant social cues that elicit caregiving/affiliative responses (attachment-related processing), and the contrast indexes positive affiliative signals (happy infant faces), so it fits the affiliation/attachment domain. Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast Neutral Face > Happy Face is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain face emotion perception contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women). It probes social processing (perception/interpretation of others' emotional expressions) and does not appear to be an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (Neutral Face > Happy Face for unknown infant faces) indexes emotional face perception/reward processing rather than an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., loved one vs stranger, parental/peer bonding, or explicit kinship/attachment paradigms). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (facial affect: Neutral > Happy) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) measuring perception/reception of facial communication (infant faces). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast Neutral Face > Happy Face indexes perception of others' infant facial expressions, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast (Sad face > Neutral face) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) probing emotional/empathetic perception of infant faces — a clear social-processing task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant facial expressions (neutral > happy), which probes perception/understanding of others' emotional states. It is not a ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore fits the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain fMRI contrast (Sad face > Neutral face) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women). The task involves perception of infant facial emotions, which indexes social/parental bonding and empathic processing relevant to affiliation and attachment, and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast Sad Face > Neutral Face is a within-group, task-evoked voxelwise contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) investigating perception of others' emotional/affective states (infant faces). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

The contrast 'Sad Face > Neutral Face' is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women), indexing reception of facial affect (a Social Communication subconstruct). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (Sad face > Neutral face) indexes perception of others' emotional infant faces, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or social self-related judgments. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group task contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

The contrast (Neutral Face > Sad Face) is a group-level, task-evoked, whole-brain univariate contrast in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) probing perception of infant facial emotion—a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast of facial affect (Neutral > Sad faces) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women), which probes reception of facial communication (affect recognition). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for the social_communication annotation.

Although the study used healthy adult participants and a whole-brain task contrast, the Neutral Face > Sad Face contrast indexes emotion perception of infant faces (valence/empathic processing) rather than an affiliation/attachment task or contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger or measures of bonding/attachment). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the analysis measure affiliation/attachment.

The contrast Neutral Face > Sad Face indexes processing of infant facial emotion (perception of others), not Perception and Understanding of Self. Although the sample and contrast appear to be a within-group whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults, the task content does not probe self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge), so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) performing an emotion face perception task; the contrast Neutral Face > Sad Face is a group-level task-evoked univariate whole-brain comparison of responses to others' (infant) emotional expressions, so it matches the Perception and Understanding of Others construct and meets inclusion (not an ROI/ connectivity or between-group) criteria.

This is a within-group, univariate whole-brain task contrast (sad > happy infant faces) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) that probes emotion perception of others (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a within‑group, whole‑brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) that compares emotional infant face conditions (sad vs happy). It assesses reception of facial communication (affect recognition), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria and does not fall under the exclusion criteria.

Although the sample (healthy nulliparous adults) and the reported contrasts appear to be group-level whole-brain task activations, the task (passive viewing of unknown infant emotional faces; contrast Sad > Happy) does not operationalize affiliation/attachment per the inclusion criteria (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, bonding/attachment measures). This contrast indexes emotional processing/empathy/reward responses to infant affect rather than affiliation/attachment specifically.

The contrast reflects perception of others' (infant) emotional expressions, not self-related processes. Although the sample and analysis appear to be a whole-brain, task-evoked group contrast in healthy adults, the task measures social/emotional perception of infants rather than Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the annotation's construct requirements.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast (Sad face > Happy face) in a sample of healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) probing perception of others' emotional states (infant facial affect). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the "perception and understanding of others" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise (whole-brain) task-evoked analysis in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) correlating brain responses to infant cries (social/emotional stimuli) with Behavioral Inhibition scores. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social processing.

Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women); contrast is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise map (high-distress infant cry > pink noise) with across-subject correlation to BIS — not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast. The stimulus is auditory infant cries (reception of non‑facial social communication), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise analysis in healthy adults (nulliparous women) correlating BIS with activation to high-distress infant cries versus pink noise. Infant cries are social/parental cues related to affiliation/attachment (caretaking response), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate contrast (high-distress infant cry > pink noise) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) with a voxelwise correlation with BIS. The task probes perception of another's emotional state (infant distress), so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group analysis in healthy adults, the contrast indexes neural responses to infant cries (social/auditory/empathic processing) rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ task-domain inclusion criteria.

This is a voxelwise, group-level contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) assessing brain responses to infant cries (social/affiliative auditory stimuli) relative to pink noise, with voxelwise correlations against BIS scores. It is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked analysis (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group contrast) and therefore meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group-level analysis in healthy adults, the contrast indexes perception of infant cries (social/auditory processing) and a correlation with a trait (BIS). It does not probe self-related processes (self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency or social comparison), so it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) assessing perception of infant cries (non‑facial social communication). The analysis is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast—it is a within-group brain activation correlated with BIS—so it meets the social_communication (reception of non‑facial communication) inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (low-distress infant cry > pink noise) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women). The task involves perception of infant cries, a social/caregiving stimulus relevant to affiliation/parent–infant attachment. The effect is a voxelwise correlation with an individual difference measure (BIS), not an ROI or connectivity analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise. The contrast indexes perception of another's emotional vocalization (infant distress), which falls under Perception/Understanding of Others. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis; the reported correlation with BIS is an individual-differences regression on the group-level map and does not make it ineligible.

Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women); contrast is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analysis (high-distress infant cry > pink noise) with a covariate (BAS Drive) — not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast. The task is social (perception of infant cries) and thus measures social processing.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise, indexing perception of an auditory social cue (reception of non-facial communication). The analysis is not ROI-, connectivity-, or between-group based, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group analysis in healthy adults (brain response to high-distress infant cries > pink noise correlated with BAS Drive), the task and contrast probe perception of infant auditory/emotional stimuli, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the annotation criterion for Perception and Understanding of Self.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise and assessing correlation with a trait (BAS Drive). The contrast indexes perception of others' emotional vocalizations (infant distress), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (animacy/emotional state perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise second-level analysis in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) correlating the task contrast (high vs low distress infant cries) with BAS Drive. The task involves perception of infant cries (a social/emotional cue), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (high vs low distress infant cries) correlated with BAS Drive in a sample of healthy adult (nulliparous) women. Infant cries are non-facial social communication (reception of vocal social signals), and the analysis is not ROI-, connectivity-, or between-group based, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cry conditions. Infant cries are attachment-relevant stimuli (caregiving/affiliation), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This contrast probes neural responses to infant cries (external social/auditory stimuli) and their correlation with a motivational trait (BAS Drive). It does not index perception/understanding of the self (self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge). Although it is a whole-brain group-level task analysis on healthy adults, the task contrast is not a self-related processing measure, so it fails the 'perception_self' inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) contrasting high- vs low-distress infant cries and correlating that task contrast with BAS Drive. The contrast probes perception of others' emotional state (infant distress), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (high-distress infant cry > pink noise) in healthy adult participants; the task (perception of infant cries) probes caregiving/attachment-relevant responses (affiliation/attachment domain). It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) examining Sad > Neutral infant faces — a social/emotion perception contrast — with brain activity correlated with BAS Drive. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, within-group voxelwise contrast (Sad face > Neutral face) in healthy adult participants viewing infant faces — a task relevant to affiliation/attachment (caregiving/infant-related social cues). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria despite using BAS Drive as a covariate.

The contrast (Sad Face > Neutral Face) reflects perception of infant emotions (others), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Although sampled healthy adults and likely whole-brain, the task/contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it fails the annotation inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrast (sad face > neutral face) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) probing perception of facial affect (Reception of Facial Communication). Although reported as a correlation with BAS Drive, this is still a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain map rather than an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

This is a whole‑brain, group‑level voxelwise contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) examining responses to others' emotional faces (sad vs neutral). Although it reports a correlation with BAS Drive (an individual‑difference covariate), it is still a within‑group task-evoked activation map probing perception/understanding of others' emotional states, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise contrast (low-distress infant cries > pink noise) with a between-subjects correlation (BAS reward) in a sample of healthy adult (nulliparous) women. The task involves perception of infant cries, a social/emotional stimulus targeting social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise and reporting voxelwise correlations with BAS Reward. Infant cries are an example of non‑facial (auditory) social communication (receptive), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (low-distress infant cry > pink noise) with voxelwise correlation to a reward-related trait (BAS Reward) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women). The task involves processing infant social cues relevant to caregiving/attachment, and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes perception of infant cries (low-distress > pink noise) and correlations with a reward trait (BAS) — an other-focused/emotional auditory stimulus task, not a measure of self-perception or self-knowledge. Although conducted in a healthy adult sample and likely a whole-brain voxelwise analysis, it does not target the Perception and Understanding of Self construct, so it should be excluded.

This analysis is a between-group contrast (Controls > Patients) from a sample including a clinical group. Inclusion requires a within-group whole-brain map from healthy adults only. Between-group comparisons are explicitly excluded, so this does not meet the criteria despite involving gesture (a social communication behavior).

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > Patients) from a schizophrenia study involving clinical participants, not an analysis on healthy adults alone. The task concerns gesture planning (praxis/social action), not an affiliation/attachment paradigm, and the contrast is a group comparison rather than a within-group whole-brain map from healthy controls. Therefore it fails the sample and contrast inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > Patients). The inclusion criteria require a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone (within-group/main effect), and the exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts (patient vs control). Therefore this analysis should be excluded.

This is a whole‑brain, group‑level voxelwise analysis in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) of a task that involves perceiving others' emotional states (infant cries). The reported map is a within‑group regression (Low‑distress cry > pink noise correlated with BAS reward), not an ROI, connectivity, or between‑group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > Patients) from a study comparing healthy controls and schizophrenia patients. Inclusion requires a within-group, whole-brain map generalizable to healthy adults (healthy-only analysis). Between-group contrasts and clinical comparisons are excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > Patients) from a study comparing healthy controls and schizophrenia patients. Inclusion requires a within-group, whole-brain map from healthy adults only. Additionally, the task probes gesture planning/execution rather than an explicit Perception/Understanding of Self contrast.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) rather than a group-level whole-brain map from the healthy/control group alone. The inclusion criteria require analyses on healthy adults (within-group) and exclude between-group contrasts, so this analysis must be excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) from a clinical study of schizophrenia, not a whole-brain group map from healthy adults alone, and the task (planning novel gestures / social action planning) does not measure affiliation/attachment per the inclusion task criteria. Therefore it fails the sample and contrast inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) from a clinical sample rather than a within-group whole-brain map of healthy adults. The inclusion rules require healthy-only, group-level univariate maps generalizable to the healthy population (no patient vs control contrasts), so this analysis must be excluded.

This analysis is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) comparing a clinical sample to healthy participants. Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone (or a within-group effect generalizable to healthy adults). Between-group contrasts and clinical-vs-control comparisons are excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) involving a clinical sample, not a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults. It therefore fails the sample and exclusion criteria (patient vs control contrast). Additionally, the task (gesture planning) does not clearly target Perception/Understanding of Self as defined.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > patients) rather than a within-group, whole-brain activation map for healthy adults alone. The inclusion rules require group-level whole-brain maps generalizable to the healthy population and exclude between-group contrasts comparing clinical and control groups.

This contrast is a between-group comparison (Controls > Patients) rather than a within-group, healthy-only whole-brain map. The inclusion rules require group-level whole-brain maps from healthy adults (not patient vs control contrasts); between-group contrasts are explicitly excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > Patients) from a mixed sample including schizophrenia patients rather than a within-group, whole-brain map from healthy adults only. It therefore fails the sample and whole-brain single-group inclusion criteria (and the task—gesture planning—is not clearly a Perception/Self measure).

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > Patients) from a study comparing healthy participants to schizophrenia patients and thus is not a group-level whole-brain map generalizable to healthy adults alone. Additionally, the task (planning/execution of gestures) does not probe affiliation/attachment processes. Both reasons exclude it per the criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > Patients) from a study comparing healthy controls and schizophrenia patients. Inclusion requires a within-group, whole-brain map from healthy adults alone; between-group contrasts are explicitly excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) for planning familiar gestures. Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain task-evoked map from healthy adults alone (or within-group contrast generalizable to healthy adults). Because this analysis compares patients to controls rather than reporting a healthy group whole-brain effect, it fails the sample/contrast inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) involving a clinical sample (schizophrenia patients) rather than an analysis on healthy adults only. Additionally, the task assesses gesture planning/execution, not an affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation, kinship). Both factors violate the inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) from a clinical vs. healthy comparison, not a within-group whole-brain map of healthy adults. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level task-evoked maps from healthy participants alone; between-group contrasts and patient samples are explicitly excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) involving a clinical sample (schizophrenia patients) rather than a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone. The inclusion criteria require healthy-only, whole-brain task-evoked maps; between-group contrasts and clinical comparisons are explicitly excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) from a mixed clinical/healthy sample rather than a within-group whole-brain map from healthy adults. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, univariate maps from healthy participants only; between-group contrasts and clinical samples are excluded.

This analysis examines planning/execution of novel and familiar gestures in a study with schizophrenia patients and healthy controls and is not a task that measures affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). In addition, the sample includes a clinical group and the table reports group comparisons, so it does not clearly meet the requirement of a whole‑brain, healthy‑adult only task-evoked map generalizable to the healthy population.

The analysis comes from a study that compares schizophrenia patients and healthy controls and the table caption describes both groups. The label "C Execution familiar gestures" does not specify a healthy/control-only, group-level whole-brain map and could represent a between-group or patient-related contrast. Because it cannot be confirmed that this is a univariate whole-brain task map from healthy adults alone (and the sample includes a clinical group), it fails the sample/whole-brain inclusion criteria.

The contrast concerns gesture execution in a study that includes schizophrenia patients and healthy controls and the analysis label does not specify that this is a whole‑brain, within‑group map from the healthy/control participants alone. Inclusion requires a group‑level voxelwise map generalizable to healthy adults; because the sample/contrast is ambiguous (and the table caption describes both patients and controls), this analysis cannot be confirmed as meeting the healthy-only whole‑brain requirement.

Although this appears to be a within-group (controls) whole-brain contrast (execution of familiar gestures), the task indexes motor planning/execution of gestures rather than processes of self-perception/self-knowledge or explicit agency judgments. It does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

This analysis is from a study that includes both schizophrenia patients and healthy controls and the table caption groups planning/execution contrasts across both groups. The label "Execution familiar gestures" refers to gesture production (execution) rather than perception/understanding of others (the annotation targets perception/understanding, e.g., action perception of others). There is no clear evidence this entry is a group-level, whole-brain univariate map from the healthy/control group alone (and it may reflect between-group contrasts). Therefore it does not meet the sample and task inclusion criteria.
